paragraphs.translated: No. Fifteen hundred infantrymen and five hundred horsemen are marching to meet Lord Lancaster, to fight against Northumberland and the Archbishop.

paragraphs.original: Comes the King back from Wales, my noble lord?
paragraphs.translated: Is the King back from Wales, my noble lord?

paragraphs.original:
You shall have letters of me presently.
Come. Go along with me, good Master Gower.
paragraphs.translated: I'll give you some letters shortly. Come with me, Master Gower.

paragraphs.original: My lord!
paragraphs.translated: Sir!

paragraphs.original: What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter?

paragraphs.original: Master Gower, shall I entreat you with me to dinner?
paragraphs.translated: Master Gower, would you like to join me for lunch?

paragraphs.original:
I must wait upon my good lord here. I thank you, good Sir
John.
paragraphs.translated: I have to attend to this noble man right here. But thank you, Sir John.

paragraphs.original:
Sir John, you loiter here too long, being you are to take
soldiers up in counties as you go.
paragraphs.translated: Sir John, you've been loitering here too long. You have to recruit soldiers in the counties you pass through on your way north.

paragraphs.original: Will you sup with me, Master Gower?
paragraphs.translated: Will you join me for supper, then, Master Gower?

paragraphs.original: What foolish master taught you these manners, Sir John?
paragraphs.translated: What foolish teacher taught you these manners, Sir John?

paragraphs.original:
Master Gower, if they become me not, he was a fool that
taught them me. - This is the right fencing grace, my lord:
tap for tap, and so part fair.
paragraphs.translated:
Master Gower, if my
manners are inappropriate, I must have indeed been taught by a fool. That's how the game is played - tit for tat, and game over.
manners

paragraphs.original: Now the Lord lighten thee. Thou art a great fool.
paragraphs.translated: God help you! You are a great fool.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and POINS
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS enter.

paragraphs.original: Before God, I am exceeding weary.
paragraphs.translated: I swear to God, I'm exceedingly tired.

paragraphs.original:
Is 't come to that? I had thought weariness durst not have
attached one of so high blood.
paragraphs.translated: Really? I would have thought that weariness wouldn't dare afflict someone as highly born as you.

paragraphs.original:
Faith, it does me; though it discolors the complexion of my
greatness to acknowledge it. Doth it not show vilely in me
to desire small beer?
paragraphs.translated:
Well, it afflicts me, although saying so dims my nobility somewhat. Does it make me seem coarse and common to say that I'd love a
small beer?
small beer

paragraphs.original:
Why, a prince should not be so loosely studied as to
remember so weak a composition.
paragraphs.translated: A prince shouldn't be vulgarly inclined toward things like small beer.

paragraphs.original:
Belike then my appetite was not princely got, for, by my
troth, I do now remember the poor creature small beer. But
indeed these humble considerations make me out of love
with my greatness. What a disgrace is it to me to remember
thy name, or to know thy face tomorrow, or to take note how
many pair of silk stockings thou hast - with these, and those
that were thy peach-colored ones - or to bear the inventory
of thy shirts, as, one for superfluity and another for use. But
that the tennis-court keeper knows better than I, for it is a
low ebb of linen with thee when thou keepest not racket
there, as thou hast not done a great while, because the rest of
the low countries have made a shift to eat up thy holland; and
God knows whether those that bawl out the ruins of thy linen
shall inherit His kingdom; but the midwives say the children
are not in the fault, whereupon the world increases and
kindreds are mightily strengthened.
paragraphs.translated: Then I suppose don't have a prince's appetite, because right now all I can think about is small beer. But it's true: all these everyday considerations distance me from my own nobility. It's disgraceful that I should be familiar with a man like you! To know your name, your face, and your wardrobe so intimately that I know that you have two pairs of stockings: the ones you're wearing now, and those peach-colored ones. I even know how many shirts you have: one to wear, and one extra. But then, the keeper of the tennis courts knows your wardrobe better than I do, for when you've run out of clean shirts, you don't show up to play. And you haven't played in a while, because the whore houses have eaten all the rest of your money, which you'd otherwise use to buy more shirts. God only knows whether all the crying brats you've fathered will make it to heaven. But then, the midwives say that babies don't bear the sins of the parents. That's how the population increases, and families are strengthened.

paragraphs.original:
How ill it follows, after you have labored so hard, you should
talk so idly! Tell me, how many good young princes would
do so, their fathers being so sick as yours at this time is?
paragraphs.translated: It seems wrong, after all your hard work in battle, that you should be spending your time now in idle chatter. How many other princes would behave like this if their fathers were as sick as yours?

paragraphs.original: Shall I tell thee one thing, Poins?
paragraphs.translated: Can I tell you something, Poins?

paragraphs.original: Yes, faith, and let it be an excellent good thing.
paragraphs.translated: Sure; and make sure it's an excellent thing.

paragraphs.original: It shall serve among wits of no higher breeding than thine.
paragraphs.translated: It'll be fine, for people who aren't any smarter than you are.

paragraphs.original: Go to. I stand the push of your one thing that you will tell.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead. I'm can take whatever you have to say.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, I tell thee it is not meet that I should be sad, now my
father is sick - albeit I could tell thee, as to one it pleases me,
for fault of a better, to call my friend, I could be sad, and sad
indeed too.
paragraphs.translated: Here it is, then. It's not seemly for me to be sad over my father's illness. But I could tell you - as a person who, for lack of anyone else, I'm pleased to call my friend - that I could be sad. I could be very sad, indeed.

paragraphs.original: Very hardly, upon such a subject.
paragraphs.translated: It would be difficult to feel that way over a thing like this.

paragraphs.original:
By this hand, thou thinkest me as far in the devil's book as
thou and Falstaff for obduracy and persistency. Let the end
try the man. But I tell thee, my heart bleeds inwardly that my
father is so sick: and keeping such vile company as thou art
hath in reason taken from me all ostentation of sorrow.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, you must think that I'm as sinful as you and Falstaff are, and as stubborn and persistent. We'll see about that. But I'm telling you: my heart is bleeding for my father, and for his illness. But because I'm hanging out with lowlifes like you, I can't show how sorrowful I am.

paragraphs.original: The reason?
paragraphs.translated: Why?

paragraphs.original: What wouldst thou think of me if I should weep?
paragraphs.translated: What would you think of me if I started crying?

paragraphs.original: I would think thee a most princely hypocrite.
paragraphs.translated: I would think you're a royal hypocrite.

paragraphs.original:
It would be every man's thought, and thou art a blessed
fellow to think as every man thinks. Never a man's thought
in the world keeps the roadway better than thine. Every man
would think me an hypocrite indeed. And what accites your
most worshipful thought to think so?
paragraphs.translated: That's what everyone would be thinking. And what's great about you is that you think just the way everyone else does: nobody sticks to popular opinion quite as well as you. Everyone would think I was a hypocrite, indeed. And, your honor, what makes you think that?

paragraphs.original:
Why, because you have been so lewd and so much engraffed
to Falstaff.
paragraphs.translated: Because you've behaved so badly, and because you're so attached to Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: And to thee.
paragraphs.translated: And to you.

paragraphs.original:
By this light, I am well spoke on. I can hear it with my own
ears. The worst that they can say of me is that I am a second
brother, and that I am a proper fellow of my hands; and those
two things, I confess, I cannot help. By the Mass, here comes
Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: Honestly, people think highly of me; I hear their praises with my own ears. The worst thing they can say about me is that, as a younger brother, I've had no inheritance from my family, and that I'm a good fighter. And I can't help either of those things. By God, here comes Bardolph.

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH and the PAGE
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and the PAGE enter.

paragraphs.original:
And the boy that I gave Falstaff. He had him from me
Christian, and look if the fat villain have not transformed
him ape.
paragraphs.translated:
And the boy who I sent to work for Falstaff. He was a normal boy when I sent him, and now look:
the fat bastard's turned him into an ape.
the fat bastard's turned him into an ape.

paragraphs.original: God save your Grace.
paragraphs.translated: God save your grace!

paragraphs.original: And yours, most noble Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated: And yours, most noble Bardolph!

paragraphs.original:
(to BARDOLPH) Come, you virtuous ass, you bashful fool,
(to
)
must you be blushing? Wherefore blush you now? What a
maidenly man-at-arms are you become! Is 't such a matter
to get a pottle-pot's maidenhead?
paragraphs.translated:
(to BARDOLPH) Come on, you principled ass, you timid fool! Why are you blushing? What a womanly solider you are! Is it that big a deal to deflower a two-quart
tankard of ale?
(to
)
tankard of ale

paragraphs.original:
He calls me e'en now, my lord, through a red lattice, and I
could discern no part of his face from the window. At last I
spied his eyes, and methought he had made two holes in the
ale-wife's new petticoat and so peeped through.
paragraphs.translated: Just now he called to me from behind a red window shade, and I couldn't tell his face from the curtain! Finally I saw his eyes, and I thought he'd made two holes in a whore's skirt and peeped through them!

paragraphs.original: Has not the boy profited?
paragraphs.translated: This kid's learned a lot from Falstaff, hasn't he?

paragraphs.original: Away, you whoreson upright rabbit, away!
paragraphs.translated: Get out of here, you little rabbit! Get out!

paragraphs.original: Away, you rascally Althea's dream, away!
paragraphs.translated: You get out, you rotten Althea's dream!

paragraphs.original: Instruct us, boy. What dream, boy?
paragraphs.translated: What dream, boy? Tell us.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, my lord, Althea dreamt she was delivered of a
firebrand, and therefore I call him her dream.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, Althea dreamed she gave birth to a red-hot iron. That's why I call him her dream; he's all red in the face.

paragraphs.original: A crown's worth of good interpretation. There 'tis, boy.
paragraphs.translated:
That joke's worth a
crown! Here you go, boy.
crown

paragraphs.original:
O, that this good blossom could be kept from cankers! Well,
there is sixpence to preserve thee.
paragraphs.translated: I wish this wholesome little flower could be kept away from disease. Well, here's a sixpence for you.

paragraphs.original:
An you do not make him hanged among you, the gallows
shall have wrong.
paragraphs.translated: If between the three of you this boy doesn't end up hanged, the gallows will be cheated.

paragraphs.original: And how doth thy master, Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: How's your master Falstaff doing, Bardolph?

paragraphs.original:
Well, my good lord. He heard of your Grace's coming to
town. There's a letter for you.
paragraphs.translated: Fine, sir. He heard you were coming to town. Here's a letter for you.

paragraphs.original:
Delivered with good respect. And how doth the Martlemas
your master?
paragraphs.translated: Delivered very respectfully. How is that fattened calf, your boss?

paragraphs.original: In bodily health, sir.
paragraphs.translated: His body's healthy, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, the immortal part needs a physician, but that moves
not him. Though that be sick, it dies not.
paragraphs.translated: That's right, it's just his immortal soul that needs a doctor. But he doesn't care. His soul may be sick, but it won't die.

paragraphs.original:
(reads to himself) I do allow this wen to be as familiar with
(reads to himself)
me as my dog, and he holds his place, for look you how be
writes. (he hands the letter to POINS)
(he hands the letter to
)
paragraphs.translated:
(reads to himself) I allow this wart to be as familiar with me as my dog, and he holds onto his privileged position. Listen to how he writes. (he hands the letter to POINS)
(reads to himself)
(he hands the letter to
)

paragraphs.original:
(reads) John Falstaff, knight. Every man must know that as
(reads)
John Falstaff, knight.
oft as he has occasion to name himself, even like those that
are kin to the King, for they never prick their finger but they
say, "There's some of the King's blood spilt." "How comes
that?" says he that takes upon him not to conceive. The
answer is as ready as a borrower's cap: "I am the King's
poor cousin, sir."
paragraphs.translated:
(reads) "John Falstaff, knight" - he always throws that title around, every chance he gets. It's like people who are related to the King: every time they get a tiny cut, they say, "Some of the King's blood has been spilled." Then someone pretends not to get it, and asks, "How do you mean?" The answer comes faster than a beggar can whip out his cap: "I'm the King's poor relative."
(reads)

paragraphs.original:
Nay, they will be kin to us, or they will fetch it from Japheth. But to the letter. (takes the letter and reads) Sir John alstaff, knight, to the son of the King nearest his father, Harry Prince of Wales, greeting.
(takes the letter and reads)
Sir John alstaff, knight, to the son of the King nearest his father, Harry Prince of Wales, greeting.
paragraphs.translated:
Right. They all say they're related to us, even if they have to trace the family tree all the way back to Japhet, the common ancestor of all Europeans. But back to the letter. (takes the letter and reads) "Sir John Falstaff - knight to the son of the King, nearest to his father, Harry Prince of Wales - sends his greetings."
(takes the letter and reads)

paragraphs.original: Why, this is a certificate.
paragraphs.translated: Listen to that. It sounds like a contract.

paragraphs.original:
Peace! (reads) I will imitate the honorable Romans in brevity.
(reads)
I will imitate the honorable Romans in brevity.
paragraphs.translated:
Quiet! (reads) "I will copy the Romans in shortness."
(reads)

paragraphs.original: He sure means brevity in breath, short-winded.
paragraphs.translated: He must mean shortness of breath, and wheezing.

paragraphs.original:
(reads) I commend me to thee, I commend thee, and I leave thee. Be not too familiar with Poins, for he misuses thy favors so much that he swears thou art to marry his sister
(reads) I commend me to thee, I commend thee, and I leave thee. Be not too familiar with Poins, for he misuses thy favors so much that he swears thou art to marry his sister
paragraphs.translated:
(reads) "I salute myself, I salute you, and I'm done. Don't get too close to Poins. He takes such rampant advantage of your kindness that he swears you will marry his sister Nell. Confess your sins when you have the time; and with that, farewell. Yours up and down
(reads)

paragraphs.original:
Nell. Repent at idle times as thou mayest, and so, farewell. Thine by yea and no, which is as much as to say, as thou usest him, Jack Falstaff with my familiars, John with my brothers and sisters, and Sir John with all Europe.
Nell. Repent at idle times as thou mayest, and so, farewell. Thine by yea and no, which is as much as to say, as thou usest him, Jack Falstaff with my familiars, John with my brothers and sisters, and Sir John with all Europe.
paragraphs.translated: (which is to say, in whatever way you feel like), I remain Jack Falstaff to my friends, John to my brothers and sisters, and Sir John to all Europe."

paragraphs.original: My lord, I'll steep this letter in sack and make him eat it.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I'll soak this letter in wine and shove it down his throat.

paragraphs.original:
That's to make him eat twenty of his words. But do you use
me thus, Ned? Must I marry your sister?
paragraphs.translated: That would be making him eat twenty of his words. But are you taking advantage of me like he says, Ned? Must I marry your sister?

paragraphs.original: God send the wench no worse fortune! But I never said so.
paragraphs.translated: It would be her lucky day if you did. But I never said that.

paragraphs.original:
Well, thus we play the fools with the time, and the spirits of
the wise sit in the clouds and mock us. (to BARDOLPH) Is your
(to
)
master here in London?
Yea, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Where sups he? Doth the old boar feed in the old frank?
paragraphs.translated: Where's he eating tonight? Is the old pig eating in the old sty?

paragraphs.original: At the old place, my lord, in Eastcheap.
paragraphs.translated: At the old place, my lord. In Eastcheap.

paragraphs.original: What company?
paragraphs.translated: Who's with him?

paragraphs.original: Ephesians, my lord, of the old church.
paragraphs.translated: The usual old characters.

paragraphs.original: Sup any women with him?
paragraphs.translated: Are any women eating with him?

paragraphs.original:
None, my lord, but old Mistress Quickly and Mistress Doll
Tearsheet.
paragraphs.translated: No women sir. Just old Mistress Quickly and Mistress Doll Tearsheet.

paragraphs.original: What pagan may that be?
paragraphs.translated: What heathen is that?

paragraphs.original:
A proper gentlewoman, sir, and a kinswoman of my
master's.
paragraphs.translated: A proper lady, sir, and my master's relative.

paragraphs.original:
Even such kin as the parish heifers are to the town bull. - 
Shall we steal upon them, Ned, at supper?
paragraphs.translated: Exactly the kind of relative as the country cows are to the town bull. Ned, should we spy on them as they eat supper?

paragraphs.original: I am your shadow, my lord. I'll follow you.
paragraphs.translated: I'm after you like a shadow, my lord: I'll follow you.

paragraphs.original:
Sirrah - you, boy - and Bardolph, no word to your master
that I am yet come to town. (gives them money) There's for
(gives them money)
your silence.
paragraphs.translated:
Sirrah, you boy, and you, Bardolph - don't tell your master that I'm back in town. (gives them money) This is for your silence.
(gives them money)

paragraphs.original: I have no tongue, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I have no tongue to speak with, sir.

paragraphs.original: And for mine, sir, I will govern it.
paragraphs.translated: As for my tongue, I'll manage it.

paragraphs.original: Fare you well. Go.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell to you both; go now.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BARDOLPH and PAGE
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and the PAGE exit.

paragraphs.original: This Doll Tearsheet should be some road.
paragraphs.translated:
This Doll Tearsheet must be some
road.
road

paragraphs.original:
I warrant you, as common as the way between Saint Alban's
and London.
paragraphs.translated: Truly, she's as well-traveled as the highway to London.

paragraphs.original:
How might we see Falstaff bestow himself tonight in his true
colors, and not ourselves be seen?
paragraphs.translated: How can we see Falstaff behave like his true self tonight, and yet not be detected ourselves?

paragraphs.original:
Put on two leathern jerkins and aprons, and wait upon him
at his table as drawers.
paragraphs.translated: We'll put on leather jackets and aprons and wait upon him as bartenders.

paragraphs.original:
From a god to a bull: a heavy decension. It was Jove's case.
From a prince to a 'prentice: a low transformation that shall
be mine, for in everything the purpose must weigh with the
folly. Follow me, Ned.
paragraphs.translated:
Should a God disguise himself as a bull? That's quite a degradation. Well,
Jove did it. And should a prince disguise himself as an apprentice bartender and transform into something so lowly? Yes, I will: in every undertaking, the ends must match the means. Follow me, Ned.
Jove

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter NORTHUMBERLAND, LADY NORTHUMBERLAND, and LADY PERCY
paragraphs.translated: NORTHUMBERLAND, LADY NORTHUMBERLAND, and LADY PERCY enter.

paragraphs.original:
I pray thee, loving wife and gentle daughter,
Give even way unto my rough affairs.
Put not you on the visage of the times
And be, like them, to Percy troublesome.
paragraphs.translated: Please, my loving wife and sweet daughter-in-law, support me in my difficult tasks. Don't let the grimness of these days be reflected in your faces; don't add to Percy's troubles.

paragraphs.original:
I have given over. I will speak no more.
Do what you will; your wisdom be your guide.
paragraphs.translated: I give up; I won't say any more. Do what you want. Let your wisdom guide you.

paragraphs.original:
Alas, sweet wife, my honor is at pawn,
And, but my going, nothing can redeem it.
paragraphs.translated: For goodness sake, sweet wife, my honor is at stake. Nothing can redeem it except my going.

paragraphs.original:
O yet, for God's sake, go not to these wars.
The time was, father, that you broke your word,
When you were more endeared to it than now,
When your own Percy, when my heart's dear Harry,
Threw many a northward look to see his father
Bring up his powers; but he did long in vain.
Who then persuaded you to stay at home?
There were two honors lost, yours and your son's.
For yours, the God of heaven brighten it.
For his, it stuck upon him as the sun
In the gray vault of heaven, and by his light
Did all the chivalry of England move
To do brave acts. He was indeed the glass
Wherein the noble youth did dress themselves.
He had no legs that practiced not his gait;
And speaking thick, which nature made his blemish,
Became the accents of the valiant;
For those that could speak low and tardily
Would turn their own perfection to abuse
paragraphs.translated:
For God's sake, don't go to these wars! Father-in-law, you once broke your word when you had better reason to keep it than you do now. Your own son Percy - my heart's beloved Harry - looked northward again and again, hoping to see his father coming with an army. But he hoped in vain. Who persuaded you to stay home that time? Two honors were lost in that battle: yours, and your son's. As for yours, I hope God will make it shine again. As for Harry's honor, it clung to him like the sun in a pale blue sky, and by its light every knight in England was moved to act bravely. He was the mirror in which noble youths dressed themselves. All men copied his way of walking, except those who had no legs.
And talking loudly and quickly - the one flaw nature had given him - became the speech pattern for all brave men. Those who spoke softly and slowly would corrupt their proper speech, just to seem more like

paragraphs.original:
To seem like him. So that in speech, in gait,
In diet, in affections of delight,
In military rules, humors of blood,
He was the mark and glass, copy and book,
That fashioned others. And him - O wondrous him!
O miracle of men! - him did you leave,
Second to none, unseconded by you,
To look upon the hideous god of war
In disadvantage, to abide a field
Where nothing but the sound of Hotspur's name
Did seem defensible. So you left him.
Never, O never, do his ghost the wrong
To hold your honor more precise and nice
With others than with him. Let them alone.
The Marshal and the Archbishop are strong.
Had my sweet Harry had but half their numbers,
Today might I, hanging on Hotspur's neck,
Have talked of Monmouth's grave.
paragraphs.translated:
Harry. In speech, bearing, and diet; in inclinations toward pleasure, in military actions, and in moods, he was the target, mirror, example, and rulebook that other men followed. And him - Oh wondrous him! Oh miracle of men! - you left him! The best man in the world, unsupported by you, faced the hideous god of war from a position of weakness. His only defense was the sound of his own name, and that is how you left him.
Never insult his memory by letting your honor count more with strangers than with him. Leave them alone: Marshal Mowbray and the Archbishop are strong. If my darling Harry had had half their army, I might be hanging on his neck today, talking about Prince Hal's grave.

paragraphs.original:
Beshrew your heart,
Fair daughter, you do draw my spirits from me
With new lamenting ancient oversights.
But I must go and meet with danger there,
Or it will seek me in another place
And find me worse provided.
paragraphs.translated: For goodness sake, pretty daughter-in-law. You take me out of myself, reminding me again of these past mistakes. But I must go and face danger there or danger will find me somewhere else, where I will be less prepared.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, fly to Scotland
Till that the nobles and the armèd commons
Have of their puissance made a little taste.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, run to Scotland until these noblemen and their
armies have skirmished against the king.

paragraphs.original:
If they get ground and vantage of the King,
Then join you with them like a rib of steel
To make strength stronger; but, for all our loves,
First let them try themselves. So did your son;
He was so suffered. So came I a widow,
And never shall have length of life enough
paragraphs.translated: If they make any headway against the King, then join them, and like a steel rod make their strength even stronger. But in the name of the love you feel for us, let them begin on their own. That's how your son fought. You allowed him to do that, and that's how I became a widow. If I spend the rest of my life pouring tears on

paragraphs.original:
To rain upon remembrance with mine eyes
That it may grow and sprout as high as heaven
For recordation to my noble husband.
paragraphs.translated: the plant of remembrance, it will never grow tall enough to pay proper tribute to my extraordinary husband.

paragraphs.original:
Come, come, go in with me. 'Tis with my mind
As with the tide swelled up unto his height,
That makes a still-stand, running neither way.
Fain would I go to meet the Archbishop,
But many thousand reasons hold me back.
I will resolve for Scotland. There am I
Till time and vantage crave my company.
paragraphs.translated: Come. Come. Go inside with me. My thoughts are like the ocean at high tide - neither coming in nor going out, seeming to stand still. I want to go join the Archbishop, but many thousands of reasons are holding me back. I'll go to Scotland and wait there till events unfold and my help is called for.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter two DRAWERS
paragraphs.translated: Two DRAWERS enter.

paragraphs.original:
What the devil hast thou brought there - applejohns? Thou
knowest Sir John cannot endure an applejohn.
paragraphs.translated:
What the hell have you got there?
Apple johns? You know Sir John can't stand apple johns.
Apple johns

paragraphs.original:
Mass, thou sayest true. The Prince once set a dish of
applejohns before him and told him there were five more Sir
Johns and, putting off his hat, said "I will now take my leave
of these six dry, round, old, withered knights." It angered
him to the heart. But he hath forgot that.
paragraphs.translated: Damn, you're right. One day the Prince put a plate of apple-johns in front of Falstaff and said, "Here are five more Sir Johns." Then the Prince took off his hat and said, "I'm now going to bid farewell to these six dry, round, old, withered knights." It angered Sir John deeply, but he got over it.

paragraphs.original:
Why then, cover, and set them down, and see if thou canst
find out Sneak's noise. Mistress Tearsheet would fain hear
some music.
paragraphs.translated: Well then, put the table cloth on and set the dish down. Go see if you can find Sneak's band of musicians. Mistress Tearsheet wants to hear some music.

paragraphs.original: Enter THIRD DRAWER
paragraphs.translated: Enter THIRD DRAWER

paragraphs.original:
Dispatch: the room where they supped is too hot. They'll
come in straight.
paragraphs.translated: Hurry! The room they ate in was too hot, and they'll be here any minute.

paragraphs.original:
Sirrah, here will be the Prince and Master Poins anon, and
they will put on two of our jerkins and aprons, and Sir John
must not know of it. Bardolph hath brought word.
paragraphs.translated: Sirrah, the Prince and Poins will be here soon. They're going to put on a couple of our jackets and aprons. Sir John can't know it's them. Bardolph came and told me.

paragraphs.original:
By the Mass, here will be old utis. It will be an excellent
stratagem.
paragraphs.translated: Well, there's going to be hilarity here! What a great scheme!

paragraphs.original: I'll see if I can find out Sneak.
paragraphs.translated: I'll see if I can find Sneak.

paragraphs.original: FRANCIS and THE DRAWERS exit
paragraphs.translated: The DRAWERS exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter MISTRESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET
paragraphs.translated: MISTRESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET enter.

paragraphs.original:
I' faith, sweetheart, methinks now you are in an excellent
good temperality. Your pulsidge beats as extraordinarily as
heart would desire, and your color, I warrant you, is as red
as any rose, in good truth, la. But, i' faith, you have drunk
too much canaries, and that's a marvellous searching wine,
and it perfumes the blood ere one can say "What's this?"
How do you now?
paragraphs.translated:
I swear, sweetheart, you seem to be in a great
temporality. Your
pulsidge is beating as strongly as you could want, and your color is as red as a rose; truly! But seriously, I do think you've drank too much of that sweet wine from the Canary Islands - it's a mighty powerful drink, and it'll get into your blood faster than you can say, "What's this?" How are you feeling now?
temporality



pulsidge

paragraphs.original: Better than I was. Hem.
paragraphs.translated:
Better than I was before. (she coughs or belches)
(she coughs or belches)

paragraphs.original:
Why, that's well said. A good heart's worth gold.
Lo, here comes Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: Well said! A healthy heart is worth its weight in gold. Look, here comes Sir John.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF enters.

paragraphs.original:
(sings) When Arthur first in court - Empty the jordan.
(sings) When Arthur first in court
(sings) And was a worthy king - How now, Mistress Doll?
(sings) And was a worthy king -
paragraphs.translated:
(singing)
"When Arthur first in court" - somebody empty the chamber pot! "And was a worthy king" - how are you, Mistress Doll?
(singing)
"When Arthur first in court" - somebody empty the chamber pot! "And was a worthy king"

paragraphs.original: Sick of a calm, yea, good faith.
paragraphs.translated:
She's sick of a
qualm, she is.
qualm

paragraphs.original: So is all her sect. An they be once in a calm, they are sick.
paragraphs.translated: That's how all the women in her profession are. As soon as they're calm - and not in someone's bed - they get sick.

paragraphs.original:
A pox damn you, muddy rascal. Is that all the comfort you
give me?
paragraphs.translated: You stupid bastard. Is this how you make me feel better?

paragraphs.original: You make fat rascals, Mistress Doll.
paragraphs.translated: You make fat bastards, Mistress Doll.

paragraphs.original:
I make them? Gluttony and diseases make them; I make
them not.
paragraphs.translated: I make them fat? Gluttony and disease will make men fat; I have nothing to do with it.

paragraphs.original:
If the cook help to make the gluttony, you help to make the
diseases, Doll. We catch of you, Doll, we catch of you. Grant
that, my poor virtue, grant that.
paragraphs.translated: Well, cooks help create gluttony, by making and selling food - the object of gluttony. And you help create diseases, Doll. We catch them from you, Doll, we catch them from you: admit it.

paragraphs.original: Yea, joy, our chains and our jewels.
paragraphs.translated: Sure, sweetheart. You catch us by the chains and the jewels, and then you steal them from us.

paragraphs.original:
Your broaches, pearls, and ouches - for to serve bravely is
to come halting off, you know; to come off the breach with
his pike bent bravely, and to surgery bravely, to venture upon
the charged chambers bravely -
paragraphs.translated:
"Your
brooches, pearls, and gems" - We fight bravely and then come away limping. We retreat from the breach in the wall with our weapons bravely bent. We head off to the doctor, bravely. And then we charge into the
loaded chambers again, bravely.
brooches, pearls, and gems"



loaded chambers

paragraphs.original: Hang yourself, you muddy conger, hang yourself!
paragraphs.translated: Drop dead, you filthy eel. Drop dead!

paragraphs.original:
By my troth, this is the old fashion. You two never meet but
you fall to some discord. You are both, i' good truth, as
rheumatic as two dry toasts. You cannot one bear with
another's confirmities. What the good-year! One must bear,
and that must be you. You are the weaker vessel, as they say,
the emptier vessel.
paragraphs.translated:
swear, this is how it always is. You two even see each other without fighting. You're as hot as dry toast, you can't stand each other's bad qualities. Good grief! But one of you has to bear the burden, and that's you, Doll. You're the weaker sex, the empty vessel.
swear

paragraphs.original:
Can a weak empty vessel bear such a huge full hogshead?
There's a whole merchant's venture of Bourdeaux stuff in
him. You have not seen a hulk better stuffed in the hold.  - 
ome, I'll be friends with thee, Jack. Thou art going to the
paragraphs.translated: Can a weak, empty vessel bear the burden of such a huge, full barrel? There's a whole merchant's stock of Bordeaux wine in him; you've never seen a ship with a fuller cargo hold. Come, Jack, I'll be friends with

paragraphs.original:
wars, and whether I shall ever see thee again or no, there is
nobody cares.
paragraphs.translated: you. You're going off to war, and whether or not I ever see you again - well, who cares.

paragraphs.original: Enter FIRST DRAWER
paragraphs.translated:
The FIRST
DRAWER enters.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, Ancient Pistol's below and would speak with
you.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, Ensign Pistol's downstairs. He wants to talk with you.

paragraphs.original:
Hang him, swaggering rascal! Let him not come hither. It is
the foul-mouthed'st rogue in England.
paragraphs.translated: Let him drop dead, that hot-tempered jerk! Don't let him in: he's got the foulest mouth in England.

paragraphs.original:
If he swagger, let him not come here. No, by my faith, I must
live among my neighbors. I'll no swaggerers: I am in good
name and fame with the very best. Shut the door. There
comes no swaggerers here. I have not lived all this while to
have swaggering now. Shut the door, I pray you.
paragraphs.translated: If he's going to make trouble, don't let him in. No way; I have my neighbors to think about. I'll have no troublemakers here. I've got my good reputation to watch out for. Shut the doors; no troublemakers are getting in here. I haven't lived this long to have trouble now. Shut the doors, please.

paragraphs.original: Dost thou hear, hostess?
paragraphs.translated: Do you hear, hostess?

paragraphs.original:
Pray you pacify yourself, Sir John. There comes no swaggerers
here.
paragraphs.translated: Please, be quiet a second, Sir John. No troublemakers are coming in here.

paragraphs.original: Dost thou hear? It is mine ancient.
paragraphs.translated: Didn't you hear? It's my ensign.

paragraphs.original:
Tilly-vally, Sir John, ne'er tell me. And your ancient
swaggerer comes not in my doors. I was before Master
Tisick, the debuty t' other day, and, as he said to me - 'twas
no longer ago than Wednesday last, i' good faith - 
"Neighbour Quickly," says he - Master Dumb, our minister,
was by then - "Neighbour Quickly," says he, "receive those
that are civil, for," said he, "you are in an ill name." Now he
said so, I can tell whereupon. "For," says he, "you are an
honest woman, and well thought on. Therefore take heed
what guests you receive. Receive," says he, "no swaggering
paragraphs.translated: Oh fiddlesticks, Sir John, I don't want to hear it. Your Ensign Troublemaker is not coming in here. I talked to Master Tisick, the deputy, the other day. And he said to me - it couldn't have been longer ago than last Wednesday - "I swear, neighbor Quickly," he said. (Master Dumbe, the minister, was here at the time.) "Neighbor Quickly," he said, "only let in people who are well behaved, because," he said, "your reputation is suffering." He said that, and I'll tell you why. "You're an honest woman, and people think highly of

paragraphs.original:
companions." There comes none here. You would bless you
to hear what he said. No, I'll no swaggerers.
paragraphs.translated: you. So think about who you let in. Don't let in," he said, "any troublemakers." And none are getting in. You'd be lucky if you heard what he said. No way, no troublemakers.

paragraphs.original:
He's no swaggerer, hostess, a tame cheater, i' faith. You may
stroke him as gently as a puppy greyhound. He'll not
swagger with a Barbary hen if her feathers turn back in any
show of resistance. - Call him up, drawer.
paragraphs.translated: He's not a troublemaker, hostess. He's a harmless cheater; you can pet him like a little puppy. He wouldn't even start a fight with a guinea-hen, if her feathers stood up in annoyance. Get him up here, drawer.

paragraphs.original: Exit FIRST DRAWER
paragraphs.translated: FIRST DRAWER exits.

paragraphs.original:
"Cheater," call you him? I will bar no honest man my house,
nor no cheater, but I do not love swaggering. By my troth,
I am the worse when one says "swagger." Feel, masters, how
I shake; look you, I warrant you.
paragraphs.translated:
You call him a
cheater? I won't keep an honest man out of this bar, so I won't keep a cheater out, either.
cheater



But I don't like troublemakers, I swear. I get sick when I hear the word, "troublemaker." Feel, masters: I'm shaking. Look, I'm telling you.

paragraphs.original: So you do, hostess.
paragraphs.translated: You are shaking.

paragraphs.original:
Do I? Yea, in very truth, do I, an 'twere an aspen leaf. I
cannot abide swaggerers.
paragraphs.translated: I am? - I am! I swear, I'm shaking like a big tree leaf. I can't stand troublemakers.

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.

paragraphs.original: God save you, Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: Good to see you, Sir John!

paragraphs.original:
Welcome, Ancient Pistol. Here, Pistol, I charge you with a
cup of sack. Do you discharge upon mine hostess.
paragraphs.translated:
Welcome, Ensign Pistol. Here,
Pistol. I charge you with a glass of wine. Now discharge on the hostess.
Pistol

paragraphs.original: I will discharge upon her, Sir John, with two bullets.
paragraphs.translated:
I'll unload two big
bullets on her, Sir John.
bullets

paragraphs.original: She is pistol-proof. Sir, you shall not hardly offend her.
paragraphs.translated: She's Pistol-proof, sir. You'll hardly be able to injure her.

paragraphs.original:
Come, I'll drink no proofs nor no bullets. I'll drink no more
than will do me good, for no man's pleasure, I.
paragraphs.translated: I won't have any proofs or any bullets. I won't drink any more than I feel like, not for any man.

paragraphs.original: Then to you, Mistress Dorothy! I will charge you.
paragraphs.translated: Then here's to you, Mistress. Dorothy, I'll charge you.

paragraphs.original:
Charge me! I scorn you, scurvy companion. What, you poor,
base, rascally, cheating lack-linen mate! Away, you mouldy
rogue, away! I am meat for your master.
paragraphs.translated: Charge me? Get lost, you sick jerk. What? You broke, rude, scheming, cheating, shirtless fool! Get away from me, you moldy bastard, away! I'm meant for your betters.

paragraphs.original: I know you, Mistress Dorothy.
paragraphs.translated: I know you, Mistress Dorothy.

paragraphs.original:
Away, you cutpurse rascal, you filthy bung, away! By this
wine, I'll thrust my knife in your mouldy chaps an you play
the saucy cuttle with me. Away, you bottle-ale rascal, you
basket-hilt stale juggler, you. Since when, I pray you, sir?
God's light, with two points on your shoulder? Much!
paragraphs.translated: Get away, you pickpocket rascal! You dirty thief, away! I swear on this wine, I'll stick a knife in your rotten cheeks if you keep abusing me like this. Out, you boozy rascal! You imposter of a solider! Since when are you a soldier, I ask you? With two armor tags on your shoulder? I'm sure!

paragraphs.original: God let me not live, but I will murder your ruff for this.
paragraphs.translated: I'll strangle your neck for that, or I'll die trying.

paragraphs.original:
No more, Pistol. I would not have you go off here. Discharge
yourself of our company, Pistol.
paragraphs.translated: Hold it, Pistol. I don't want you to go off here. Discharge someplace else, Pistol.

paragraphs.original: No, good Captain Pistol, not here, sweet captain.
paragraphs.translated: No, good Captain Pistol. Not here, sweet captain.

paragraphs.original:
Captain? Thou abominable damned cheater, art thou not
ashamed to be called captain? An captains were of my mind,
they would truncheon you out for taking their names upon
you before you have earned them. You a captain? You slave,
paragraphs.translated: Captain? You horrible, damned liar, aren't you ashamed to be called "captain"? If captains shared my opinions, they'd beat you for taking their rank without earning it. You, a captain? You bastard, for what? For

paragraphs.original:
for what? For tearing a poor whore's ruff in a bawdy house?
He a captain! Hang him, rogue. He lives upon mouldy
stewed prunes and dried cakes. A captain? God's light, these
villains will make the word as odious as the word "occupy,"
which was an excellent good word before it was ill sorted.
Therefore captains had need look to 't.
paragraphs.translated:
tearing a poor whore's clothes in a whorehouse? Him, a captain? Let him drop dead, the rogue! He lives off the moldy food you find in brothels. A captain? For God's sake! Men like him will make the word "captain" as nasty as the word
"occupy," which was a fine word before it got corrupted. Captains had better watch out.
"occupy,"

paragraphs.original: Pray thee go down, good ancient.
paragraphs.translated: Please, calm down, good ensign.

paragraphs.original: Hark thee hither, Mistress Doll.
paragraphs.translated: Listen here, Mistress Doll.

paragraphs.original:
Not I. I tell thee what, Corporal Bardolph, I could tear her.
I'll be revenged of her.
paragraphs.translated: Not me. I'll tell you what, Corporal Bardolph, I could tear her. I'll get revenge on her.

paragraphs.original: Pray thee go down.
paragraphs.translated: Please, calm down!

paragraphs.original:
I'll see her damned first to Pluto's damnèd lake, by this
hand, to th' infernal deep with Erebus and tortures vile also.
Hold hook and line, say I. Down, down, dogs! Down, Fates!
Have we not Hiren here?
paragraphs.translated: I'll see her damned first. To the waters of hell, I swear, to the endless deep, with chaos and vile tortures. Hold onto that pole, I say. Down, down, dogs! Down, fates! Here's my sword!

paragraphs.original:
Good Captain Peesell, be quiet. 'Tis very late, i' faith. I
beseek you now, aggravate your choler.
paragraphs.translated: Captain Pisser, be quiet! It's late. I beg of you, stop being angry!

paragraphs.original:
These be good humors indeed. Shall pack-horses
And hollow pampered jades of Asia, which cannot go but
thirty mile a day,
Compare with Caesars and with cannibals, and Troyant
Greeks? Nay, rather damn them with King
Cerberus, and let the welkin roar. Shall we fall foul
for toys?
paragraphs.translated:
Now we're talking! Are we going to let old
nags and pampered horses (who can't manage more than a few miles a day) be compared with kings, and generals, and mythic heroes? No! Damn them to hell, and let the storms rage! Should we fight over nothing?
nags

paragraphs.original: By my troth, captain, these are very bitter words.
paragraphs.translated: My goodness, captain! Those are strong words!

paragraphs.original: Begone, good ancient. This will grow to a brawl anon.
paragraphs.translated: You should go now, ensign. This is going to get out of control in a minute.

paragraphs.original:
Die men like dogs! Give crowns like pins! Have we not
Hiren here?
paragraphs.translated: Let men die like dogs! Give away kings' crowns like they're nothing! Isn't this a sword we have here?

paragraphs.original:
O' my word, captain, there's none such here. What the good-
year, do you think I would deny her? For God's sake, be
quiet.
paragraphs.translated:
My
word of honor, captain, there's no such thing here! For goodness sake! Do you think I'd say she's not if she were? For God's sake, be quiet!
word of honor

paragraphs.original:
Then feed and be fat, my fair Calipolis. Come, give 's some
sack. Si fortune me tormente, sperato me contento. Fear we
Si fortune me tormente, sperato me contento.
broadsides? No, let the fiend give fire. Give me some sack,
and, sweetheart, lie thou there. (lays down his sword) Come
(lays down his sword)
we to full points here? And are etceteras nothing?
paragraphs.translated:
Then eat and grow fat, my sweet lady! Come, bring me some wine. Si
fortuna me tormente, sperato me contento. Are we scared of an attack? No! Let the devil open fire. Give me some wine, and darling, lie there. (he lays his sword down) Is the party over? What about the rest of it, the
et ceteras?
Si
fortuna me tormente



sperato me contento.
(he lays his sword down)
et ceteras

paragraphs.original: Pistol, I would be quiet.
paragraphs.translated: Pistol, I'd be quiet if I were you.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet knight, I kiss thy neaf. What, we have seen the seven
stars.
paragraphs.translated: Sweet knight, I kiss your fist. Look! It's so late - we can see the Big Dipper out.

paragraphs.original:
For God's sake, thrust him downstairs. I cannot endure such
a fustian rascal.
paragraphs.translated: For God's sake, throw him down the stairs. I can't stand such a worthless jerk.

paragraphs.original: "Thrust him downstairs"? Know we not Galloway nags?
paragraphs.translated: Throw him down the stairs? Don't we know a common prostitute when we see one?

paragraphs.original:
Quoit him down, Bardolph, like a shove-groat shilling. Nay,
an he do nothing but speak nothing, he shall be nothing here.
paragraphs.translated: Toss him down, Bardolph, like a coin on a game board. He does nothing but talk a bunch of nothing, so he's going to count for nothing here.

paragraphs.original: Come, get you downstairs.
paragraphs.translated: Come on. Get downstairs.

paragraphs.original:
What! shall we have incision? Shall we imbrue? (snatches up his sword) Then death rock me asleep, abridge my doleful
(snatches up his sword)
days. Why then, let grievous, ghastly, gaping wounds
untwine the Sisters Three. Come, Atropos, I say.
paragraphs.translated:
What? Is there going to be
cutting now? Shall we be soaked in blood? (he grabs his sword) Then let death sing me a lullaby; let him end my melancholy days! Let grievous, ghastly, gaping wounds unravel the thread of my life, spun by those three sisters of fate! Come, Atropos, cut off my thread!
cutting



(he grabs his sword)

paragraphs.original: Here's goodly stuff toward!
paragraphs.translated: This ought to be good.

paragraphs.original: Give me my rapier, boy.
paragraphs.translated: Give me my sword, boy.

paragraphs.original: I pray thee, Jack, I pray thee do not draw.
paragraphs.translated: Please, Jack, please; don't fight!

paragraphs.original:
Get you downstairs. (drawing and driving PISTO out)
(drawing and driving
out)

Here's a goodly tumult. I'll forswear keeping house afore
I'll be in these tirrits and frights. So, murder, I warrant now.
Alas, alas, put up your naked weapons, put up your naked
weapons.
paragraphs.translated: This is going to be some fight! I would sooner close this bar than put up with terrors and fits. It's murder, I swear! Oh my! Oh my! Put away your naked weapons! Put away your naked weapons!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PISTOL pursued by BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL exits, pursued by BARDOLPH.

paragraphs.original:
I pray thee, Jack, be quiet. The rascal's gone. Ah, you
whoreson little valiant villain, you.
paragraphs.translated: Please, Jack, calm down; the jerk's gone. Oh you son-of-a-bitch, brave little bastard, you!

paragraphs.original: Are you not hurt i' the groin? Methought he made a shrewd thrust at your belly.
paragraphs.translated: Did he hurt you in the groin? I thought he got in a good shot at your belly.

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH enters.

paragraphs.original: Have you turned him out o' doors?
paragraphs.translated: Did you kick him out of here?

paragraphs.original: Yea, sir. The rascal's drunk. You have hurt him, sir, i' the shoulder.
paragraphs.translated: Yup! The jerk's drunk. You hurt his shoulder.

paragraphs.original: A rascal to brave me!
paragraphs.translated: That jerk! How dare he challenge me!

paragraphs.original:
Ah, you sweet little rogue, you. Alas, poor ape, how thou
sweat'st! Come, let me wipe thy face. Come on, you
whoreson chops. Ah, rogue, i' faith, I love thee. Thou art as
valorous as Hector of Troy, worth five of Agamemnon, and
ten times better than the Nine Worthies. Ah, villain!
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, you sweet little rogue, you! Oh my, you poor monkey, you're sweating! Come, let me wipe your face. Come on, you fat bastard. Oh, you rogue! I swear, I love you. You're as brave as
Hector of Troy, you're worth five Agamemnons, and you're ten times better than the nine wonders of the world! Oh, you villain!
Hector of Troy

paragraphs.original: Ah, rascally slave! I will toss the rogue in a blanket.
paragraphs.translated: The no-good jerk! I'll wrap the rogue in a blanket, the way they punish cowards.

paragraphs.original:
Do, an thou darest for thy heart. An thou dost, I'll canvass
thee between a pair of sheets.
paragraphs.translated: Do it, if you dare. If you do, I'll toss you between a pair of sheets!

paragraphs.original: Enter musicians
paragraphs.translated: The musicians enter.

paragraphs.original: The music is come, sir.
paragraphs.translated: The music is here, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Let them play. - Play, sirs. - Sit on my knee, Doll. A rascal
bragging slave! The rogue fled from me like quicksilver.
paragraphs.translated: Let them play. Play, sirs. Sit on my knee, Doll. A no-good, bragging jerk! The fool ran from me like quicksilver.

paragraphs.original:
I' faith, and thou followed'st him like a church. Thou
whoreson little tidy Bartholomew boar-pig, when wilt thou
leave fighting a-days and foining a-nights and begin to patch
up thine old body for heaven?
paragraphs.translated: Truly, and you chased him like a church - slowly. You rotten little fat roasting pig! When will you stop fighting all day and thrusting all night, and start to get your body ready for its final resting place?

paragraphs.original: Enter, behind, PRINCE HENRY and POINS, disguised as drawers
paragraphs.translated: Unseen, PRINCE HENRY and POINS enter, disguised as drawers.

paragraphs.original:
Peace, good Doll. Do not speak like a death's-head; do not bid
me remember mine end.
paragraphs.translated:
Quiet, Doll. Don't talk like a
death's-head. Don't make me think of my own end.
death's-head

paragraphs.original: Sirrah, what humor's the Prince of?
paragraphs.translated:
Sirrah, what's the
Prince like?
Prince

paragraphs.original:
A good shallow young fellow, he would have made a good
pantler; he would a' chipped bread well.
paragraphs.translated: He's a shallow youngster. He would have made a good pantry servant: he would have been great at trimming the crusts off bread.

paragraphs.original: They say Poins has a good wit.
paragraphs.translated: They say Poins is smart.

paragraphs.original:
He a good wit? Hang him, baboon. His wit's as thick as
Tewksbury mustard. There's no more conceit in him than is
in a mallet.
paragraphs.translated: Him, smart? Hang him, he's a baboon! He's as thick as mustard, and no smarter than a sledgehammer.

paragraphs.original: Why does the Prince love him so then?
paragraphs.translated: Then why does the Prince love him?

paragraphs.original:
Because their legs are both of a bigness, and he plays at
quoits well, and eats conger and fennel, and drinks off
candles' ends for flap-dragons, and rides the wild mare with
the boys, and jumps upon joint stools, and swears with a
good grace, and wears his boots very smooth, like unto the
sign of the Leg, and breeds no bate with telling of discreet
stories, and such other gambol faculties he has that show a
weak mind and an able body, for the which the Prince admits
him; for the Prince himself is such another. The weight of a
hair will turn the scales between their avoirdupois.
paragraphs.translated: Because their legs are the same size, and he likes to play the game of quoits and eat fatty foods; and he'll play drinking games, like dropping burning candle ends into his drinks. He plays on the see-saw with the boys, and pulls crazy stunts, and curses nicely. And his boots fit nice and smooth, just like the ones painted on the shoe store's signs. And he doesn't cause trouble by spilling secrets. He has all kinds of qualities associated with weak minds and healthy bodies, and that's why the Prince keeps him around: because the Prince is exactly the same. There's not a hair's difference between the two of them.

paragraphs.original: Let's beat him before his whore.
paragraphs.translated: Let's beat him in front of his whore.

paragraphs.original:
Look whe'er the withered elder hath not his poll clawed like
a parrot.
paragraphs.translated:
Look at that old
geezer having his head scratched like a parrot.
geezer

paragraphs.original:
Is it not strange that desire should so many years outlive
performance?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't it odd that desire lasts so much longer than the ability to perform?

paragraphs.original: Kiss me, Doll.
paragraphs.translated: Kiss me, Doll.

paragraphs.original:
Saturn and Venus this year in conjunction! What says th'
almanac to that?
paragraphs.translated:
Saturn and Venus must be aligned this year! What do you think the astrological tables have to say about that?
Saturn and Venus

paragraphs.original:
And look whether the fiery trigon, his man, be not lisping to
his master's old tables, his notebook, his counsel keeper.
paragraphs.translated: And look. That fiery-faced Bardolph is whispering sweet nothings to Quickly, his master's old confidante.

paragraphs.original: By my troth, I kiss thee with a most constant heart.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, my kisses are heartfelt.

paragraphs.original: I am old, I am old.
paragraphs.translated: I'm old. I'm old.

paragraphs.original:
I love thee better than I love e'er a scurvy young boy of them
all.
paragraphs.translated: I love you more than I could love any ridiculous young man in the world.

paragraphs.original:
What stuff wilt have a kirtle of? I shall receive money o'
Thursday; shalt have a cap tomorrow. A merry song! Come,
it grows late. We'll to bed. Thou 'lt forget me when I am
gone.
paragraphs.translated: What fabric do you want a new skirt made out of? I'll get paid on Thursday, so you'll get a new hat tomorrow. Let's have a happy song. It's getting late; let's go to bed. You'll forget me when I'm gone.

paragraphs.original:
By my troth, thou 'lt set me a-weeping an thou sayest so.
Prove that ever I dress myself handsome till thy return. Well,
harken a' th' end.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, you'll make me cry if you talk like that. I won't wear any beautiful clothing till you return. Well, we'll see what happens.

paragraphs.original: Some sack, Francis.
paragraphs.translated: Some wine, Francis.

paragraphs.original: Anon, anon, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Right away, sir!

paragraphs.original: Coming forward
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY and POINS reveal themselves.

paragraphs.original:
Ha? A bastard son of the King's? - And art not thou
Poins his brother?
paragraphs.translated: What! A bastard son of the King? And aren't you Poins, his brother?

paragraphs.original:
Why, thou globe of sinful continents, what a life dost thou
lead?
paragraphs.translated: Your globe, covered with continents of sin! What kind of life are you leading?

paragraphs.original: A better than thou. I am a gentleman. Thou art a drawer.
paragraphs.translated: A better life than you. I'm a gentleman and you're just a drawer.

paragraphs.original: Very true, sir, and I come to draw you out by the ears.
paragraphs.translated: That's right, sir. And I'm going to draw you out of this room by the ears.

paragraphs.original:
O, the Lord preserve thy good Grace! By my troth, welcome
to London. Now the Lord bless that sweet face of thine. O
Jesu, are you come from Wales?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, may God bless you, sir. I swear, welcome to London. God bless that sweet face of yours! Oh Jesus! Have you come from Wales?

paragraphs.original:
Thou whoreson mad compound of majesty, (indicating
(indicating
DOLL) by this light flesh and corrupt blood, thou art welcome.
)
How? You fat fool, I scorn you.
paragraphs.translated: What? You fat fool! The hell with you!

paragraphs.original:
My lord, he will drive you out of your revenge and turn all
to a merriment, if you take not the heat.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, if you don't strike while the iron's hot, he'll turn everything into a joke and rob you of your chance for revenge.

paragraphs.original:
You whoreson candle-mine, you how vilely did you speak of
me even now before this honest, virtuous, civil
gentlewoman!
paragraphs.translated: You son of a whore, you giant piece of candle wax, you said such horrible things about me just now, in front of this honest, upstanding and well-behaved lady.

paragraphs.original: God's blessing of your good heart, and so she is, by my troth.
paragraphs.translated: May God bless your good heart! She is all that, I swear.

paragraphs.original: Didst thou hear me?
paragraphs.translated: Did you hear me?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, and you knew me, as you did when you ran away by
Gad's Hill. You knew I was at your back, and spoke it on
purpose to try my patience.
paragraphs.translated:
Yes. And you knew I was there, right? It's just like when you ran away at
Gad's Hill : you knew I was the one who beat you, and you made up some story just to irritate me.
Gad's Hill

paragraphs.original: No, no, no; not so. I did not think thou wast within hearing.
paragraphs.translated: No, no, no. Not at all. I had no idea you were there.

paragraphs.original:
I shall drive you, then, to confess the wilfull abuse, and then
I know how to handle you.
paragraphs.translated: Then I'm going to make you confess that you deliberately slandered me. And then I'll know what to do next.

paragraphs.original: No abuse, Hal, o' mine honor, no abuse.
paragraphs.translated: No slander, Hal. On my honor, no slander.

paragraphs.original:
Not to dispraise me and call me pantier and bread-chipper
and I know not what?
paragraphs.translated: No? To malign me, and call me a pantry servant and a bread-trimmer, and I don't know what else?

paragraphs.original: No abuse, Hal.
paragraphs.translated: No slander, Hal.

paragraphs.original: No abuse?
paragraphs.translated: No slander?

paragraphs.original:
No abuse, Ned, i' th' world, honest Ned, none. I dispraised
him before the wicked, that the wicked might not fall in love
with thee; in which doing, I have done the part of a careful
friend and a true subject, and thy father is to give me thanks
for it. No abuse, Hal. - None, Ned, none. No, faith, boys, none.
paragraphs.translated: No slander, Ned, in the world, honest Ned, none. I maligned him only to the wicked, so that the wicked wouldn't fall in love with him. And by doing that, I've acted like a good friend and loyal subject, and your father should thank me for it. No slander, Hal, none, Ned. No, truly boys, none.

paragraphs.original:
See now whether pure fear and entire cowardice doth not
make thee wrong this virtuous gentlewoman to close with
us. Is she of the wicked, is thine hostess here of the wicked,
or is thy boy of the wicked, or honest Bardolph, whose zeal
burns in his nose, of the wicked?
paragraphs.translated: Now your absolute fear and utter cowardliness has made you wrong this good lady in order to make peace with us. Is she wicked? Is this hostess here wicked? Is your boy here wicked? Or honest Bardolph, whose piety burns in his face? Is he wicked?

paragraphs.original: Answer, thou dead elm, answer.
paragraphs.translated: Answer, you withered old trunk, answer.

paragraphs.original:
The fiend hath pricked down Bardolph irrecoverable, and
his face is Lucifer's privy kitchen, where he doth nothing but
roast malt-worms. For the boy, there is a good angel about
him, but the devil outbids him too.
paragraphs.translated: The devil has marked Bardolph as long gone, and his face is Lucifer's kitchen, where only drunks are served. As for the boy, he may have a good spirit on one shoulder, but the devil on the other is stronger.

paragraphs.original: For the women?
paragraphs.translated: And the women?

paragraphs.original:
For one of them, she's in hell already and burns poor souls.
For the other, I owe her money, and whether she be damned
for that I know not.
paragraphs.translated: One of them is in hell already, where she gets poor souls hot. As for the other, I owe her money. If she's damned for that, I have no idea.

paragraphs.original: No, I warrant you.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not, I promise you that.

paragraphs.original:
No, I think thou art not; I think thou art quit for that. Marry,
there is another indictment upon thee for suffering flesh to
be eaten in thy house contrary to the law, for the which I
think thou wilt howl.
paragraphs.translated: No, I think you're not. I think you've been excused for that. But there's another charge against you. You serve flesh in this place, and that's against the law. You're going to hell for that.

paragraphs.original:
All vitlars do so. What's a joint of mutton or two in a whole
Lent?
paragraphs.translated: Everybody who serves food does that. What's wrong with a bite or two of meat during Lent?

paragraphs.original: You, gentlewoman.
paragraphs.translated: You, good lady -

paragraphs.original: What says your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: What is it, gracious sir?

paragraphs.original: His grace says that which his flesh rebels against.
paragraphs.translated: He may speak to you graciously, but his body feels otherwise.

paragraphs.original: Knocking within
paragraphs.translated: Knocking is heard offstage.

paragraphs.original: Who knocks so loud at door? Look to th' door there, Francis.
paragraphs.translated: Who's knocking so loudly on the door? Francis, go see.

paragraphs.original: Enter PETO
paragraphs.translated: PETO enters.

paragraphs.original: Peto, how now, what news?
paragraphs.translated: Peto, how are you? What's going on?

paragraphs.original:
The King your father is at Westminster,
And there are twenty weak and wearied posts
Come from the north, and as I came along
I met and overtook a dozen captains,
Bareheaded, sweating, knocking at the taverns
And asking everyone for Sir John Falstaff.
paragraphs.translated: Your father the King is in Westminster. Twenty exhausted messengers have arrived from the north. And, on my way here, I met a dozen captains, hustling and working hard, knocking on the door of every tavern and searching for Sir John Falstaff.

paragraphs.original:
By heaven, Poins, I feel me much to blame
So idly to profane the precious time
When tempest of commotion, like the south
Borne with black vapour, doth begin to melt
And drop upon our bare unarmèd heads. - 
Give me my sword and cloak. - Falstaff, good night.
paragraphs.translated: My God, Poins, I feel terrible wasting precious time on this idleness when a huge black storm is brewing, soon to open up on our bare, vulnerable heads. Give me my coat and my sword. Good night, Falstaff.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO and BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY, POINS, PETO, and BARDOLPH exit.

paragraphs.original: Now comes in the sweetest morsel of the night, and we must hence and leave it unpicked.
paragraphs.translated: Now's the sweetest part of the night, and we have to leave without enjoying it.

paragraphs.original: Knocking within
paragraphs.translated: Knocking is heard offstage.

paragraphs.original: More knocking at the door?
paragraphs.translated: More knocking!

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, what's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on? What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
You must away to court, sir, presently.
A dozen captains stay at door for you.
paragraphs.translated: You have to go to the royal court immediately, sir. A dozen captains are at the door waiting for you.

paragraphs.original:
(to the PAGE) Pay the musicians, sirrah. - Farewell,
(to the
)
hostess. - Farewell, Doll. You see, my good wenches, how
men of merit are sought after. The undeserver may sleep
when the man of action is called on. Farewell, good
wenches. If I be not sent away post, I will see you again ere
I go.

I cannot speak. If my heart be not ready to burst - well,
sweet Jack, have a care of thyself.
paragraphs.translated: I can't speak; my heart is ready to burst. Well, sweet Jack, take care of yourself.

paragraphs.original: Farewell, farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Farewell, farewell.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, PAGE, and musicians
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF and BARDOLPH exit.

paragraphs.original:
Well, fare thee well. I have known thee these twenty-nine
years, come peascod time, but an honester and truer-hearted
man - well, fare thee well.
paragraphs.translated: Well, goodbye. I've known you twenty-nine years this June. But a more honest, more good-hearted man - well, fare you well.

paragraphs.original:
(within) Mistress Tearsheet!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Mistress Tearsheet!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original: What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: What's the matter?

paragraphs.original:
(within) Bid Mistress Tearsheet come to my master.
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Mistress Tearsheet, come to my master.
(offstage)

paragraphs.original:
O, run, Doll, run, run, good Doll. Come. - She comes
blubbered. - Yea! Will you come, Doll?
paragraphs.translated: O, run, Doll, run; run, good Doll. Come. - She's coming, all crying and blubbering. - Will you come, Doll?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter KING Henry in his nightgown, with a page
paragraphs.translated: KING Henry enters, wearing his nightgown. A page follows.
Call the earls of Surrey and Warwick. Tell them to read over these letters before they come, and to think carefully about them. Hurry.

paragraphs.original: Exit page
paragraphs.translated: The page exits.

paragraphs.original:
How many thousand of my poorest subjects
Are at this hour asleep! O sleep, O gentle sleep,
Nature's soft nurse, how have I frighted thee,
That thou no more wilt weigh my eyelids down
And steep my senses in forgetfulness?
Why rather, sleep, liest thou in smoky cribs,
Upon uneasy pallets stretching thee
And hushed with buzzing night-flies to thy slumber,
Than in the perfumed chambers of the great,
Under the canopies of costly state,
And lull'd with sound of sweetest melody?
O thou dull god, why liest thou with the vile
In loathsome beds and leavest the kingly couch
A watch-case or a common 'larum bell?
Wilt thou upon the high and giddy mast
Seal up the shipboy's eyes, and rock his brains
In cradle of the rude imperious surge
And in the visitation of the winds,
Who take the ruffian billows by the top,
Curling their monstrous heads and hanging them
With deafening clamor in the slippery clouds
That with the hurly death itself awakes?
Canst thou, O partial sleep, give thy repose
To the wet sea-boy in an hour so rude,
paragraphs.translated:
Thousands of even my poorest subjects are sleeping right now. Oh sleep! Oh sweet sleep, nature's gentle healer, what have I done to frighten you? You won't weigh down my eyelids anymore, or dull my mind to make me forget. Sleep, why do you lie in filthy hovels, stretched out on uncomfortable cots, where insects' buzzing is the lullaby? Why don't you lie in the sweet-smelling bedrooms of kings, under opulent canopies, lulled with soft and beautiful music? You drowsy god, why do you lie with the common people in their loathsome beds, leaving the royal bed lonely like a sentry post, or a bell tower?
Will you even close the eyes of a ship boy, high up on the whirling mast, and rock him gently in a cradle made of rough, tossing seas and howling winds - winds which take the waves and, curling them over, crashes them through the air with such a deafening noise that they wake death itself? Can you, oh unfair sleep, give rest to a drenched little sailor in the midst of such roughness, and yet deny it to a king?

paragraphs.original:
And, in the calmest and most stillest night,
With all appliances and means to boot,
Deny it to a king? Then, happy low, lie down.
Uneasy lies the head that wears a crown.
paragraphs.translated: A king on the calmest, stillest night, with everything available for sleep? Then, you happy commoners, put yourselves to bed. The head that wears the crown sleeps uneasily.

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK and SURREY
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK and SURREY enter.

paragraphs.original: Many good morrows to your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, your highness.

paragraphs.original: Is it good morrow, lords?
paragraphs.translated: Is it morning, lords?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis one o'clock, and past.
paragraphs.translated: It's after one o'clock.

paragraphs.original:
Why then, good morrow to you all, my lords.
Have you read o'er the letter that I sent you?
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, good morning to you all, my lords. Have you read the letters I sent you?

paragraphs.original: We have, my liege.
paragraphs.translated: We have, your highness.

paragraphs.original:
Then you perceive the body of our kingdom
How foul it is, what rank diseases grow
And with what danger near the heart of it.
paragraphs.translated: Then you can tell how sick the kingdom is. There are serious diseases spreading through its body, very near its heart.

paragraphs.original:
It is but as a body yet distempered,
Which to his former strength may be restored
With good advice and little medicine.
My Lord Northumberland will soon be cooled.
paragraphs.translated: The body's only out of sorts. It can be brought back to full health through good care and some medicine. Northumberland will soon be suppressed.

paragraphs.original:
O God, that one might read the book of fate
And see the revolution of the times
Make mountains level, and the continent,
Weary of solid firmness, melt itself
Into the sea, and other times to see
The beachy girdle of the ocean
Too wide for Neptune's hips; how chance's mocks
And changes fill the cup of alteration
paragraphs.translated: Oh God! If only we could read the book of destiny! We'd see how time changes everything, bringing mountains low and melting the land - which is tired of being solid and firm - into the sea. We'd see how the beach is sometimes too wide for even the tide to conquer. We'd see how blind luck can make mockeries of men, and how change can affect you in countless ways.

paragraphs.original:
With divers liquors! O, if this were seen,
The happiest youth, viewing his progress through,
What perils past, what crosses to ensue,
Would shut the book, and sit him down and die.
'Tis not ten years gone
Since Richard and Northumberland, great friends,
Did feast together, and in two years after
Were they at wars. It is but eight years since
This Percy was the man nearest my soul,
Who like a brother toiled in my affairs
And laid his love and life under my foot,
Yea, for my sake, even to the eyes of Richard
Gave him defiance. But which of you was by - 
(to WARWICK) You, cousin Nevil, as I may remember - 
(to
)
When Richard, with his eye brimful of tears,
Then checked and rated by Northumberland,
Did speak these words, now proved a prophecy?
"Northumberland, thou ladder by the which
My cousin Bolingbroke ascends my throne" - 
Though then, God knows, I had no such intent,
But that necessity so bowed the state
That I and greatness were compelled to kiss - 
"The time shall come," thus did he follow it,
"The time will come that foul sin, gathering head,
Shall break into corruption" - so went on,
Foretelling this same time's condition
And the division of our amity.
paragraphs.translated:
If even the happiest youth could read this book, he'd look at the course of his life - the dangers he's endured, the challenges that still lie ahead - and he'd shut that book, sit down and die. It was less than ten years ago that Richard and Northumberland loved each other. Then two years later, they were at war. Just eight years ago, Northumberland was the man closest to my heart. Like a brother, he devoted himself to me, dedicating both life and limb to my cause. He even challenged Richard on my behalf. But which of you was there - 
I think it was you, Warwick - when Richard, his eyes brimming with tears because of Northumberland's rebellion, spoke these words that now seem prophetic: "Northumberland, you are the ladder that Bolingbroke has climbed to get to the throne." Although, God knows, it wasn't my intention then to become king. But the country needed it so badly, I was forced to rise up and become great. "The time will come," Richard continued, "when this terrible sin, growing in size, will break out into corruption." That's how he went on. He predicted our current condition, and the collapse of our alliances.

paragraphs.original:
There is a history in all men's lives
Figuring the nature of the times deceased,
The which observed, a man may prophesy,
With a near aim, of the main chance of things
As yet not come to life, which in their seeds
And weak beginnings lie intreasurèd.
Such things become the hatch and brood of time,
And by the necessary form of this,
paragraphs.translated: There is a chronicle for every man's life, which shows what happened to him in times now past. If you study that chronicle, you can prophecy what lies ahead with some accuracy. The seeds of things to come are buried in the things that have already happened. These seeds grow, and become the children of time.

paragraphs.original:
King Richard might create a perfect guess
That great Northumberland, then false to him,
Would of that seed grow to a greater falseness,
Which should not find a ground to root upon
Unless on you.
paragraphs.translated: King Richard could look at the pattern of what had gone before and predict perfectly that Northumberland's betrayal - then still a seed - would someday grow larger, if it could find suitable soil to root in. And you're the only soil it could have found.

paragraphs.original:
Are these things then necessities?
Then let us meet them like necessities.
And that same word even now cries out on us.
They say the Bishop and Northumberland
Are fifty thousand strong.
paragraphs.translated: Were these things necessary, then? Then we'll treat them like necessities, even though the very word "necessities" cries out against us. They say the Archbishop and Northumberland have fifty thousand men in their army.

paragraphs.original:
It cannot be, my lord.
Rumor doth double, like the voice and echo,
The numbers of the feared. Please it your Grace
To go to bed. Upon my soul, my lord,
The powers that you already have sent forth
Shall bring this prize in very easily.
To comfort you the more, I have received
A certain instance that Glendower is dead.
Your Majesty hath been this fortnight ill,
And these unseasoned hours perforce must add
Unto your sickness.
paragraphs.translated: That can't be, my lord. Rumor, like an echo, doubles the size of our enemy's army. Please, your highness, go to bed. I swear on my soul that the army you've already sent out can win this battle easily. And here's more good news: I've heard for sure that Glendower is dead. You've been ill for two weeks now, your majesty. Keeping such irregular hours will surely make things worse.

paragraphs.original:
I will take your counsel.
And were these inward wars once out of hand,
We would, dear lords, unto the Holy Land.
paragraphs.translated: I'll listen to your advice. And once we've got this civil war in hand, we will, my friends, march to the Holy Land.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter Justice SHALLOW and Justice SILENCE, with MOULDY, SHADOW, WART, FEEBLE, BULLCALF, and a servant or two
paragraphs.translated: Justice SHALLOW and Justice SILENCE enter. They are followed by MOULDY, SHADOW, WART, FEEBLE, BULLCALF, and a servant or two.

paragraphs.original:
Come on, come on, come on. Give me your hand, sir, give
me your hand, sir. An early stirrer, by the rood. And how
doth my good cousin Silence?
paragraphs.translated: Come on, come on, come on, sir. Shake my hand, sir, shake my hand. You're an early riser, I swear. How are you, cousin Silence?

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, good cousin Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, cousin Shallow.

paragraphs.original:
And how doth my cousin your bedfellow? And your fairest
daughter and mine, my goddaughter Ellen?
paragraphs.translated: And how's my cousin, your wife? And your prettiest daughter, my fair god-daughter Ellen?

paragraphs.original: Alas, a black ousel, cousin Shallow.
paragraphs.translated:
I'm afraid she's got
dark hair, cousin Shallow!
dark hair

paragraphs.original:
By yea and no, sir. I dare say my cousin William is become
a good scholar. He is at Oxford still, is he not?
paragraphs.translated: By gum, I bet William's become a real scholar. He's still at Oxford, right?

paragraphs.original: Indeed, sir, to my cost.
paragraphs.translated: He sure is, and I'm the one who's paying for it.

paragraphs.original:
He must then to the Inns o' Court shortly. I was once of
Clement's Inn, where I think they will talk of mad Shallow
yet.
paragraphs.translated:
He'll be going to law school soon. I studied law at
Clement's Inn, where I think they still talk about crazy old Shallow.
Clement's Inn
