become very hot and valiant. If I had a thousand sons, the
first human principle I would teach them should be to
forswear thin potations and to addict themselves to sack.
paragraphs.translated: the same way, except that we're always drunk. A good sherry wine operates in two ways. First, it rises into the brain and dries out all the foolish, dull, clogged-up fogs that have gathered there. It makes the brain sharp, quick, and inventive; full of nimble, fiery, and beautiful ideas. The voice and tongue give birth to those ideas which, when they grow up, become excellent wit. The second power of good wine is the warming of the blood. Before wine, the blood is cold and sluggish, and this makes the liver - the organ of passion - chilly and pale. A chilly, pale liver is the sign of cowardice and faint-heartedness. But wine warms the blood, making it course from the inner organs to all the extremities. The blood brightens the face, and the rest of the body - which is like a little kingdom in itself - takes that brightening as a signal. Then the spirits of the blood and all the internal organs gather together behind their captain: the heart. The heart draws strength from these followers and, enlarged by them, can accomplish any courageous deed. This is the bravery that comes from wine. Without wine, skill in weaponry doesn't matter. Wine is what sets that skill in motion. Education is nothing more than idle gold in the devil's hands, until wine rouses it and puts it to good use. That's how Prince Harry became valiant. He's taken the cold blood he inherited from his father and - like unproductive farmland - he fertilized it, planted it, and cared for it, through the hard work of drinking vast amounts of good and potent wine. And so now, he's become hot and courageous. If I had a thousand sons, the first rule of behavior I would teach them would be to avoid weak drinks, and get themselves addicted to wine.

paragraphs.original: Enter BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: What is it, Bardolph?

paragraphs.original: The army is discharged all and gone.
paragraphs.translated: The army is dismissed, and everyone's gone.

paragraphs.original:
Let them go. I'll through Gloucestershire, and there will I
visit Master Robert Shallow, Esquire. I have him already
temp'ring between my finger and my thumb, and shortly
will I seal with him. Come away.
paragraphs.translated: Let them go. I'll head to Gloucestershire. I'll visit Master Robert Shallow, Esquire. I've already got him under my thumb, as soft as wax. Soon I'll seal the deal. Let's go.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter KING Henry, his sons Thomas Duke of CLARENCE and Humphrey Duke of GLOUCESTER, with WARWICK and others
paragraphs.translated: KING Henry, his sons Thomas Duke of CLARENCE and Humphrey Duke of GLOUCESTER, WARWICK, and others enter.

paragraphs.original:
Now, lords, if God doth give successful end
To this debate that bleedeth at our doors,
We will our youth lead on to higher fields
And draw no swords but what are sanctified.
Our navy is addressed, our power collected,
Our substitutes in absence well invested,
And everything lies level to our wish.
Only we want a little personal strength;
And pause us till these rebels now afoot
Come underneath the yoke of government.
paragraphs.translated: Now, my lords: if God grants us a victory in this violent civil war that bleeds at our very doorsteps, I will lead our young people in a greater cause, and fight nothing but holy wars. Our navy is ready, our army is assembled, the leaders who are my subordinates have their orders, and everything is standing by to achieve my main aim. The only drawback is that I'm feeling a little weak. So let's wait a short while, until the rebels, now on the run, are brought back in line and are made obedient again.

paragraphs.original:
Both which we doubt not but your Majesty
Shall soon enjoy.
paragraphs.translated: We are sure that you'll soon enjoy both good health and the rebels' defeat.

paragraphs.original:
Humphrey, my son of Gloucester,
Where is the Prince your brother?
paragraphs.translated: My son Humphrey of Gloucester, where is your brother, Prince Hal?

paragraphs.original: I think he's gone to hunt, my lord, at Windsor.
paragraphs.translated: I think he's gone hunting at Windsor.

paragraphs.original: And how accompanied?
paragraphs.translated: Who's with him?

paragraphs.original: I do not know, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know, father.

paragraphs.original: Is not his brother Thomas of Clarence with him?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't his brother, Thomas of Clarence, with him?

paragraphs.original: No, my good lord, he is in presence here.
paragraphs.translated: No, father. He's here.

paragraphs.original: What would my lord and father?
paragraphs.translated: What is it you'd like, father?

paragraphs.original:
Nothing but well to thee, Thomas of Clarence.
How chance thou art not with the Prince thy brother?
He loves thee, and thou dost neglect him, Thomas.
Thou hast a better place in his affection
Than all thy brothers. Cherish it, my boy,
And noble offices thou mayst effect
Of mediation, after I am dead,
Between his greatness and thy other brethren.
Therefore omit him not; blunt not his love,
Nor lose the good advantage of his grace
By seeming cold or careless of his will.
For he is gracious if he be observed;
He hath a tear for pity and a hand
Open as day for melting charity;
Yet notwithstanding, being incensed he is flint,
As humorous as winter, and as sudden
As flaws congealed in the spring of day.
His temper therefore must be well observed.
Chide him for faults, and do it reverently,
When thou perceive his blood inclined to mirth;
But, being moody, give him time and scope
Till that his passions, like a whale on ground,
Confound themselves with working. Learn this, Thomas,
And thou shalt prove a shelter to thy friends,
A hoop of gold to bind thy brothers in,
That the united vessel of their blood,
Mingled with venom of suggestion
(As, force perforce, the age will pour it in),
Shall never leak, though it do work as strong
As aconitum or rash gunpowder.
paragraphs.translated:
Only good things for you, Thomas. Why aren't you with the Prince, your brother? He loves you and you are neglecting him. He cares more about you than any of his other brothers, Thomas; cherish that fact, my boy. After I'm dead, you'll be in a strong position to help maintain good relations between Prince Hal and his brothers.
So don't ignore him. Don't turn away his love, and don't ruin your good relationship with him by seeming cold or distant. He's kind if he gets his way; he has compassion for others, and he's generous with charity. But despite all this, once he gets angry, he becomes like a stone. He can be as tempestuous as winter, and can change himself as suddenly as snowflakes at dawn can turn to hail. So watch his temper.
When he does something wrong, let him know it - gently, and when he's in a happy mood. But when he's ornery, give him room. Wait till his bad mood works itself out, like a beached whale that kills itself by struggling to return to sea. If you can do this, you'll be a shelter for your friends, and a golden chain that links your brothers together. Once they're united, the poison of criticism and rumor - which in this day and age is sure to be aimed at them - can't do them any harm, no matter how explosive and destructive it may be.

paragraphs.original: I shall observe him with all care and love.
paragraphs.translated: I'll watch over him with as much care and love as possible.

paragraphs.original: Why art thou not at Windsor with him, Thomas?
paragraphs.translated: Then why aren't you with him at Windsor?

paragraphs.original: He is not there today; he dines in London.
paragraphs.translated: He's not there today. He's in London.

paragraphs.original: And how accompanied? Canst thou tell that?
paragraphs.translated: Who's with him? Do you know?

paragraphs.original: With Poins and other his continual followers.
paragraphs.translated: Poins, and the usual suspects.

paragraphs.original:
Most subject is the fattest soil to weeds,
And he, the noble image of my youth,
Is overspread with them; therefore my grief
Stretches itself beyond the hour of death.
The blood weeps from my heart when I do shape,
In forms imaginary, th' unguided days
And rotten times that you shall look upon
When I am sleeping with my ancestors.
For when his headstrong riot hath no curb,
When rage and hot blood are his counsellors,
When means and lavish manners meet together,
O, with what wings shall his affections fly
Towards fronting peril and opposed decay!
paragraphs.translated:
Weeds grow best in the richest soil, and he - like myself at that age - is overrun by them. My sadness, then, cannot end with my death. When I imagine the lawless days and rotten times that you will face when I am dead and sleeping with my ancestors, the blood weeps from my heart.
When Hal's headstrong wildness has free rein; when aggression and passion are his advisors; when he has full opportunity to indulge in his riotous inclinations, then - Oh! - his criminal desires will fly like a bird towards danger and ruin.

paragraphs.original:
My gracious lord, you look beyond him quite.
The Prince but studies his companions
Like a strange tongue, wherein, to gain the language,
'Tis needful that the most immodest word
Be looked upon and learned; which, once attained,
Your Highness knows, comes to no further use
But to be known and hated. So, like gross terms,
The Prince will, in the perfectness of time,
Cast off his followers, and their memory
Shall as a pattern or a measure live,
By which his Grace must mete the lives of others,
Turning past evils to advantages.
paragraphs.translated: Your highness, you've got him all wrong. The Prince is only studying his criminal companions, the way one studies a foreign language. In order to truly learn a language, one must learn even the most immodest curse word - which, as you know, is only learned in order to be identified and, thereafter, avoided. So, like vulgar language, the Prince will get rid of his followers when the time is right. Then they'll live on in his memory as guidelines, by which he'll judge the conduct of others. In this sense, he'll change his past bad deeds to good ends.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis seldom when the bee doth leave her comb
In the dead carrion.
paragraphs.translated: It's rare that a bee builds its nest in a dead animal's carcass. The Prince won't leave his current company.

paragraphs.original: Enter WESTMORELAND
paragraphs.translated: WESTMORELAND enters.

paragraphs.original: Who's here? Westmoreland?
paragraphs.translated: Who's there? Westmoreland?

paragraphs.original:
Health to my sovereign, and new happiness
Added to that that I am to deliver.
Prince John your son doth kiss your Grace's hand.
Mowbray, the Bishop Scroop, Hastings, and all
Are brought to the correction of your law.
There is not now a rebel's sword unsheathed
But peace puts forth her olive everywhere.
The manner how this action hath been borne
Here at more leisure may your Highness read
With every course in his particular.
paragraphs.translated:
I wish your highness good health, and happy news beyond the report I have to deliver! Prince John sends his respects: Mowbray, the Archbishop, Hastings and the rest are under arrest. There are no more rebels anywhere; the olive branch of peace has been extended everywhere.
Here's a letter explaining what happened. When you have time, you can read it and learn every detail.

paragraphs.original:
O Westmoreland, thou art a summer bird,
Which ever in the haunch of winter sings
The lifting up of day.
paragraphs.translated: Oh Westmoreland; you're like a summer bird, which sings the dawn in as winter ends.

paragraphs.original: Enter HARCOURT
paragraphs.translated: HARCOURT enters.

paragraphs.original: Here comes more news.
paragraphs.translated: Look, here's more news.

paragraphs.original:
From enemies heaven keep your Majesty,
And when they stand against you, may they fall
As those that I am come to tell you of.
The Earl Northumberland and the Lord Bardolph,
With a great power of English and of Scots,
Are by the shrieve of Yorkshire overthrown.
The manner and true order of the fight
This packet, please it you, contains at large.
paragraphs.translated: May heaven protect your highness from all enemies - and when they do rise up, may they fall just like the ones I've come to tell you about. The Earl of Northumberland and Lord Bardolph, with their mighty armies of Englishmen and Scotsmen, were defeated by the Sheriff of Yorkshire. This letter will tell you the details.

paragraphs.original:
And wherefore should these good news make me sick?
Will fortune never come with both hands full,
But write her fair words still in foulest letters?
She either gives a stomach and no food -
paragraphs.translated: Why am I sick at this good news? Why can't life ever bring you things with their appropriate complements? Why is good news so often conveyed in ugly terms? Life either gives you hunger but no food - which is the

paragraphs.original:
Such are the poor, in health - or else a feast
And takes away the stomach - such are the rich,
That have abundance and enjoy it not.
I should rejoice now at this happy news,
And now my sight fails, and my brain is giddy.
O, me! Come near me, now I am much ill.
paragraphs.translated: experience of poor, healthy people - or it gives you a feast with no appetite - which is how the rich live, who have wealth and abundance but cannot enjoy it. I should be celebrating this good news, and yet my eyesight is failing, and my brain is delirious. Oh God! Come to me, I'm very sick.

paragraphs.original: Comfort, your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: Take care, your highness!

paragraphs.original: O, my royal father!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my royal father!

paragraphs.original: My sovereign lord, cheer up yourself, look up.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, feel better; take courage.

paragraphs.original:
Be patient, princes. You do know these fits
Are with his Highness very ordinary.
Stand from him, give him air. He'll straight be well.
paragraphs.translated: Wait a minute, princes. You know his highness has these episodes all the time. Move away from him. Give him air; he'll be all right soon.

paragraphs.original:
No, no, he cannot long hold out these pangs.
Th' incessant care and labor of his mind
Hath wrought the mure that should confine it in
So thin that life looks through and will break out.
paragraphs.translated: No, no, he can't survive these attacks much longer. His mind's endless worry and concern have so shaken his body that it can barely hold together.

paragraphs.original:
The people fear me, for they do observe
Unfathered heirs and loathly births of nature.
The seasons change their manners, as the year
Had found some months asleep and leapt them over.
paragraphs.translated: The people are frightening me. They've seen terrible omens: children who seem to have supernatural fathers, and gruesomely deformed infants. The weather is in disarray, as if the calendar discovered some months were fast asleep, and decided to skip over them.

paragraphs.original:
The river hath thrice flowed, no ebb between,
And the old folk, time's doting chronicles,
Say it did so a little time before
That our great-grandsire, Edward, sicked and died.
paragraphs.translated: The river has flooded three times, without receding between floods. The old people - those living history books - say that the last time this happened was when our great-grandfather, King Edward, fell ill and died.

paragraphs.original: Speak lower, princes, for the King recovers.
paragraphs.translated: Speak more softly, princes: the King is recovering.

paragraphs.original: This apoplexy will certain be his end.
paragraphs.translated: These attacks will be the death of him.

paragraphs.original:
I pray you, take me up and bear me hence
Into some other chamber. Softly, pray.
paragraphs.translated: Please, carry me into another room. Quietly. Please.

paragraphs.original: They carry the KING to a bed.
paragraphs.translated: They carry the KING to a bed.

paragraphs.original:
Let there be no noise made, my gentle friends,
Unless some dull and favorable hand
Will whisper music to my weary spirit.
paragraphs.translated: Please be silent, my friends, unless someone can play some restful, whispering music for my exhausted spirit.

paragraphs.original: Call for the music in the other room.
paragraphs.translated: Call the musicians in from the other room.

paragraphs.original: Set me the crown upon my pillow here.
paragraphs.translated: Put the crown here on my pillow.

paragraphs.original: His eye is hollow, and he changes much.
paragraphs.translated: His eyes are sunken, and he seems very pale.

paragraphs.original: Less noise, less noise.
paragraphs.translated: Less noise, less noise!

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY enters.

paragraphs.original: Who saw the Duke of Clarence?
paragraphs.translated: Has anybody seen the Duke of Clarence?

paragraphs.original: I am here, brother, full of heaviness.
paragraphs.translated: I'm here, brother, full of sadness.

paragraphs.original:
How now! Rain within doors, and none abroad?
How doth the King?
paragraphs.translated: What's going on? Raining inside while it's dry outside? How's the King?

paragraphs.original: Exceeding ill.
paragraphs.translated: Extremely sick.

paragraphs.original: Heard he the good news yet? Tell it him.
paragraphs.translated: Has he heard the good news yet? Tell him.

paragraphs.original: He altered much upon the hearing it.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, he heard it, and it affected him deeply.

paragraphs.original: If he be sick with joy, he'll recover without physic.
paragraphs.translated: If he's sick from joy, then he'll get better without medicine.

paragraphs.original:
Not so much noise, my lords. - Sweet Prince, speak low.
The King your father is disposed to sleep.
paragraphs.translated: Not so loud, sirs. Prince, speak more quietly. Your father the King is trying to sleep.

paragraphs.original: Let us withdraw into the other room.
paragraphs.translated: Let's go into the other room.

paragraphs.original: Will 't please your Grace to go along with us?
paragraphs.translated: Will you come with us?

paragraphs.original: No, I will sit and watch here by the King.
paragraphs.translated: No. I'll stay here with the King.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except PRINCE HENRY.

paragraphs.original:
Why doth the crown lie there upon his pillow,
Being so troublesome a bedfellow?
O polished perturbation, golden care,
That keep'st the ports of slumber open wide
To many a watchful night! sleep with it now;
Yet not so sound and half so deeply sweet
As he whose brow with homely biggen bound
Snores out the watch of night. O majesty,
When thou dost pinch thy bearer, thou dost sit
Like a rich armor worn in heat of day,
That scald'st with safety. By his gates of breath
There lies a downy feather which stirs not;
Did he suspire, that light and weightless down
Perforce must move. My gracious lord, my father,
This sleep is sound indeed. This is a sleep
That from this golden rigol hath divorced
So many English kings. Thy due from me
Is tears and heavy sorrows of the blood,
Which nature, love, and filial tenderness
Shall, O dear father, pay thee plenteously.
My due from thee is this imperial crown,
Which, as immediate as thy place and blood,
paragraphs.translated: Why does the crown lie there on his pillow, when it's such a troublesome bedfellow? Oh polished aggravation, golden anxiety! You keep the eyelids open wide, to face countless sleepless nights. You sleep with the crown now, father, but you don't sleep as soundly, or half so deeply, as that man whose head is bound with nothing more than a cheap nightcap, who snores through the night. Oh, you crown! When you pinch the person wearing you, you're like a great suit of armor worn on a hot day - you burn the person you're protecting. There's a feather near my father's lips, and it's not moving: if he were breathing, that light, weightless thing would move. My gracious lord! Father! This is a deep sleep indeed - this is a sleep that has removed the golden ring from the heads of many English kings. Father, I owe you tears and a deep grief, and my love, the bonds of family, and a son's tender feelings will make sure that I pay you lavishly. Your debt to me is this kingly crown, which I am owed as your heir-apparent.

paragraphs.original:
Derives itself to me. (he puts the crown on his head) Lo,
(he puts the crown on his head)
where it sits,
Which God shall guard. And put the world's whole strength
Into one giant arm, it shall not force
This lineal honor from me. This from thee
Will I to mine leave, as 'tis left to me.
paragraphs.translated:
(he puts the crown on his head) Look, here it sits, and God will guard it. Even if all the strength in the world were gathered into a single, giant arm, it wouldn't be able to force this inherited honor from me. I will leave this to my son as you've left it to me.
(he puts the crown on his head)

paragraphs.original: Exit PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY exits.

paragraphs.original:
(waking) Warwick! Gloucester! Clarence!
(waking)
paragraphs.translated:
(waking) Warwick! Gloucester! Clarence!
(waking)

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK, GLOUCESTER, CLARENCE, and the rest enter.

paragraphs.original: Doth the King call?
paragraphs.translated: Did you call, sir?

paragraphs.original: What would your Majesty? How fares your Grace?
paragraphs.translated: What can we do for you, your highness? How are you feeling?

paragraphs.original: Why did you leave me here alone, my lords?
paragraphs.translated: Why did you leave me alone, sirs?

paragraphs.original:
We left the Prince my brother here, my liege,
Who undertook to sit and watch by you.
paragraphs.translated: We left my brother, Prince Hal, here. He decided to sit with you.

paragraphs.original:
The Prince of Wales? Where is he? Let me see him.
He is not here.
paragraphs.translated: The Prince of Wales? Where is he? I want to see him. He's not here.

paragraphs.original: This door is open. He is gone this way.
paragraphs.translated: This door's open. He went this way.

paragraphs.original: He came not through the chamber where we stayed.
paragraphs.translated: He didn't come through the room we were in.

paragraphs.original: Where is the crown? Who took it from my pillow?
paragraphs.translated: Where's the crown? Who took it off my pillow?

paragraphs.original: When we withdrew, my liege, we left it here.
paragraphs.translated: When we left, sir, it was here.

paragraphs.original:
The Prince hath ta'en it hence. Go seek him out.
Is he so hasty that he doth suppose my sleep my death?
Find him, my Lord of Warwick. Chide him hither.
paragraphs.translated: The Prince has taken it. Go, find him. Is he in such a hurry that he thinks my sleep is my death? Find him, Lord Warwick. Rebuke him, and bring him here.

paragraphs.original: Exit WARWICK
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK exits.

paragraphs.original:
This part of his conjoins with my disease
And helps to end me. See, sons, what things you are,
How quickly nature falls into revolt
When gold becomes her object!
For this the foolish overcareful fathers
Have broke their sleep with thoughts,
Their brains with care, their bones with industry.
For this they have engrossèd and piled up
The canker'd heaps of strange-achievèd gold.
For this they have been thoughtful to invest
Their sons with arts and martial exercises - 
When, like the bee, tolling from every flower
The virtuous sweets,
Our thighs packed with wax, our mouths with honey,
We bring it to the hive and, like the bees,
Are murdered for our pains. This bitter taste
Yield his engrossments to the ending father.
paragraphs.translated: Henry's actions join forces with my illness, and together they will kill me. Sons, look at what things you are. See how quickly blood bonds are broken, once money's involved. This is what happens to foolish, overly concerned fathers who ruin their sleep with worry, burden their minds with anxiety, and break their bodies with hard work. This is what happens to fathers who amass vast amounts of money, earned in unsavory ways. This is what happens to fathers who have taken care to give their sons good educations, and train them in matters of war. Fathers are like bees, collecting sweet pollen from all the flowers in the world. We pack our thighs full of wax and our mouths full of honey, only to be killed when we return to the hive. This is the bitter fate of the dying father, no matter what he has accumulated in his life.

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK enters.

paragraphs.original:
Now, where is he that will not stay so long
Till his friend sickness hath determined me?
paragraphs.translated: Where is that impatient man who can't even wait for his friend, sickness, to put an end to me?

paragraphs.original:
My lord, I found the Prince in the next room,
Washing with kindly tears his gentle cheeks,
With such a deep demeanor in great sorrow
That tyranny, which never quaffed but blood,
Would, by beholding him, have washed his knife
With gentle eyedrops. He is coming hither.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I found the Prince in the next room, with tears flowing down his cheeks. He looked so sorrowful that a tyrant - who never drank anything but blood - would, upon seeing him, have washed the blood from his knife with tears. He's on his way.

paragraphs.original: But wherefore did he take away the crown?
paragraphs.translated: But why did he take away the crown?

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY enters.

paragraphs.original:
Lo where he comes. - Come hither to me, Harry. - 
Depart the chamber. Leave us here alone.
paragraphs.translated:
Look, here he comes. Come here, Harry. (to the rest) Leave the room, and leave us here alone.
(to the rest)

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but the KING and PRINCE HENRY
paragraphs.translated: Everyone leaves except the KING and PRINCE HENRY.

paragraphs.original: I never thought to hear you speak again.
paragraphs.translated: I never thought I'd hear you speak again.

paragraphs.original:
Thy wish was father, Harry, to that thought.
I stay too long by thee; I weary thee.
Dost thou so hunger for mine empty chair
That thou wilt needs invest thee with my honors
Before thy hour be ripe? O foolish youth,
Thou seek'st the greatness that will overwhelm thee.
Stay but a little, for my cloud of dignity
Is held from falling with so weak a wind
That it will quickly drop. My day is dim.
Thou hast stol'n that which after some few hours
Were thine without offense, and at my death
Thou hast sealed up my expectation.
Thy life did manifest thou loved'st me not,
And thou wilt have me die assured of it.
Thou hid'st a thousand daggers in thy thoughts,
Which thou hast whetted on thy stony heart
To stab at half an hour of my life.
What, canst thou not forbear me half an hour?
Then get thee gone and dig my grave thyself,
And bid the merry bells ring to thine ear
That thou art crownèd, not that I am dead.
Let all the tears that should bedew my hearse
Be drops of balm to sanctify thy head;
Only compound me with forgotten dust.
Give that which gave thee life unto the worms.
Pluck down my officers, break my decrees,
paragraphs.translated:
You thought that because you wished it to be true. I live too long for you; you're tired of me. Are you so desperate for my throne that you would take the honors of kingship before it's your time? Oh you foolish youth! You long for power that will end up overwhelming you. Wait a little while. What power I have left is held together so weakly that the lightest breeze would blow it away: my life is fading.
You stole something from me that would freely have been yours in just a few hours. On my deathbed, you've confirmed all my expectations. All your life you showed that you didn't love me, and now I will die certain of it. There are a thousand daggers in your thoughts, which you've sharpened on your stony heart with the hopes of stabbing me in the little time I have left. What? Couldn't you endure me for half an hour? Then go and dig my grave yourself, and ring the bells to mark your coronation, not my death. Let all the tears that should be shed on my hearse be drops of holy water to bless your head.

paragraphs.original:
For now a time is come to mock at form.
Harry the Fifth is crowned. Up, vanity,
Down, royal state, all you sage counsillors, hence,
And to the English court assemble now,
From every region, apes of idleness.
Now, neighbor confines, purge you of your scum.
Have you a ruffian that will swear, drink, dance,
Revel the night, rob, murder, and commit
The oldest sins the newest kind of ways?
Be happy, he will trouble you no more.
England shall double gild his treble guilt.
England shall give him office, honor, might,
For the fifth Harry from curbed license plucks
The muzzle of restraint, and the wild dog
Shall flesh his tooth on every innocent.
O my poor kingdom, sick with civil blows!
When that my care could not withhold thy riots,
What wilt thou do when riot is thy care?
O, thou wilt be a wilderness again,
Peopled with wolves, thy old inhabitants.
paragraphs.translated: Just mix me up with the forgotten dust, and give my body - which gave you life - to the worms. Fire my officers, undo my laws; for now the time has come to jeer at authority. Henry the Fifth is crowned: up with foolishness! Down with decorum! Be gone, all you wise advisers! Assemble lazy apes from every region, and make them the royal court of England! Now, you neighboring countries, get rid of your scum. Do you have a criminal who swears, drinks, dances, parties all night, robs, murders, and commits the oldest sins in the newest ways? Then be happy: that man won't trouble you any longer. England will paint over his guilt with gold. England will give him a position, honor, power. Because Henry the Fifth has removed the barriers to anarchy: he's taken the restraining muzzle off the dog of misbehavior, and that wild dog will sink his teeth into the flesh of every decent person. Oh my poor kingdom, sick from this civil war! When all my hard work couldn't keep disorder at bay, what will you do when disorder becomes your caretaker? Oh, you'll be a wilderness again, and all the wolves who lived here once will once again be your only citizens.

paragraphs.original:
O pardon me, my liege! But for my tears,
The moist impediments unto my speech,
I had forestalled this dear and deep rebuke
Ere you with grief had spoke and I had heard
The course of it so far. There is your crown,
And He that wears the crown immortally
Long guard it yours. If I affect it more
Than as your honor and as your renown,
Let me no more from this obedience rise,
Which my most inward true and duteous spirit
Teacheth this prostrate and exterior bending.
God witness with me, when I here came in
And found no course of breath within your Majesty,
How cold it struck my heart! If I do feign,
O, let me in my present wildness die
paragraphs.translated: Oh forgive me, your highness. If it weren't for these tears - which are impeding my speech - I would have stopped this harsh scolding before you, in your grief, had spoken and before I had listened so long. There's your crown. May God, who wears the crown eternally, guard it as yours for a long time. If I care for the crown in any way other than as a symbol of your honor and reputation, let me never rise from this kneeling position. It is my deepest and most dutiful feelings which teach my body to bend and bow to you, causing my outer body to reflect my inner feelings. May God be my witness: when I came in here and saw that you weren't breathing, my blood ran cold. If I'm lying,

paragraphs.original:
And never live to show th' incredulous world
The noble change that I have purposèd.
Coming to look on you, thinking you dead,
And dead almost, my liege, to think you were,
I spake unto this crown as having sense,
And thus upbraided it: "The care on thee depending
Hath fed upon the body of my father;
Therefore thou best of gold art worst of gold.
Other, less fine in carat, is more precious,
Preserving life in med'cine potable;
But thou, most fine, most honored, most renowned,
Hast eat thy bearer up." Thus, my most royal liege,
Accusing it, I put it on my head
To try with it, as with an enemy
That had before my face murdered my father,
The quarrel of a true inheritor.
But if it did infect my blood with joy
Or swell my thoughts to any strain of pride,
If any rebel or vain spirit of mine
Did with the least affection of a welcome
Give entertainment to the might of it,
Let God forever keep it from my head
And make me as the poorest vassal is
That doth with awe and terror kneel to it.
paragraphs.translated:
may I die as the wild youth I was before, and never live to show the dubious world the transformation I have been planning.
Coming to see you, thinking you were dead - and being nearly dead myself, just thinking that you were - I spoke to this crown as though it were alive. I scolded it like this: "The worry you've caused has eaten my father alive. So you, the best piece of gold, are actually the worst piece of gold. Other gold, perhaps worth less, is more precious, since it at least brings us health when mixed in our drinks. But you - the best, the most honored, the most famous - have consumed the person wearing you." And as I accused it, I put it on my head, to fight against it as an enemy who'd killed my father before my very eyes. It was the fight of a loyal child.
But may God keep it from me forever - making me like the poorest servant bowing down before it in awe and terror - if it in any way made me happy or arrogant, or if any part of me was the least bit pleased to welcome it and the power it brings.

paragraphs.original:
O my son,
God put it in thy mind to take it hence
That thou mightst win the more thy father's love,
Pleading so wisely in excuse of it.
Come hither, Harry, sit thou by my bed
And hear, I think, the very latest counsel
That ever I shall breathe. God knows, my son,
By what bypaths and indirect crook'd ways
I met this crown, and I myself know well
How troublesome it sat upon my head.
To thee it shall descend with better quiet,
paragraphs.translated:
Oh my son, God made you take it from me so that, in pleading your case so beautifully, you would make me love you more! Come here, Harry. Sit by my bed and listen to what I think will be the last advice I ever give. God knows the unusual paths and indirect, crooked ways that led me to this crown.
And I know very well how much anxiety it has caused as I've worn it. It will fall to you in bitter peace, with

paragraphs.original:
Better opinion, better confirmation,
For all the soil of the achievement goes
With me into the earth. It seemed in me
But as an honor snatched with boist'rous hand,
And I had many living to upbraid
My gain of it by their assistances,
Which daily grew to quarrel and to bloodshed,
Wounding supposèd peace. All these bold fears
Thou see'st with peril I have answerèd,
For all my reign hath been but as a scene
Acting that argument. And now my death
Changes the mood, for what in me was purchased
Falls upon thee in a more fairer sort.
So thou the garland wear'st successively.
Yet though thou stand'st more sure than I could do,
Thou art not firm enough, since griefs are green,
And all my friends, which thou must make thy friends,
Have but their stings and teeth newly ta'en out,
By whose fell working I was first advanced
And by whose power I well might lodge a fear
To be again displaced; which to avoid,
I cut them off and had a purpose now
To lead out many to the Holy Land,
Lest rest and lying still might make them look
Too near unto my state. Therefore, my Harry,
Be it thy course to busy giddy minds
With foreign quarrels; that action, hence borne out,
May waste the memory of the former days.
More would I, but my lungs are wasted so
That strength of speech is utterly denied me.
How I came by the crown, O God forgive,
And grant it may with thee in true peace live.
paragraphs.translated:
better support and stronger approval. The stain of its obtainment dies now, with me. On me, the crown seemed like an honor grabbed with a violent hand, and many people lived to remind me that they had helped me take it. Eventually, those daily reminders grew into war and bloodshed, doing damage to the peace. You can see how much pain it's caused me as I've fought my foes. My entire reign has been like a play, in which we rehash that disagreement.
Now my death changes the show. What I bought, you will inherit. You'll wear the crown by right of succession. But even though you have a firmer claim to the crown than I had, it's not firm enough. Anger is still fresh, and my former friends - whom you must make into your friends - have only recently been disarmed. It was their power that first got me the crown, and I feared that same power could take me down. To avoid that, I defeated their rebellion, and planned to lead an army to the Holy Land. I thought that, with nothing to occupy themselves, they'd start eyeing me and my crown.
Therefore, my Harry, make it your policy to focus the distracted minds of the people with foreign wars. Military actions abroad will make people forget about troubling matters in the past. I'd say more, but my lungs are so worn out that I don't have the strength to speak. God forgive me for how I came by the crown, and may he grant that you enjoy it in peace.

paragraphs.original:
My gracious liege,
You won it, wore it, kept it, gave it me.
paragraphs.translated: My gracious lord, you won it, wore it, kept it, then gave it to me. My possession of it must therefore be honest

paragraphs.original:
Then plain and right must my possession be,
Which I with more than with a common pain
'Gainst all the world will rightfully maintain.
paragraphs.translated: and lawful. And I will work as hard as I can to defend this crown against any man.

paragraphs.original: Enter Lord John of LANCASTER
paragraphs.translated: Lord John of LANCASTER enters.

paragraphs.original: Look, look, here comes my John of Lancaster.
paragraphs.translated: Look, look, here comes my son, John of Lancaster.

paragraphs.original: Health, peace, and happiness to my royal father.
paragraphs.translated: Health, peace, and happiness to my royal father!

paragraphs.original:
Thou bring'st me happiness and peace, son John,
But health, alack, with youthful wings is flown
From this bare withered trunk. Upon thy sight
My worldly business makes a period.
Where is my Lord of Warwick?
paragraphs.translated: You bring me happiness and peace, John. But health, unfortunately, has flown from this shrunken body. Now that I've seen you, I have nothing more to do in this world. Where is Lord Warwick?

paragraphs.original: My Lord of Warwick.
paragraphs.translated: Lord Warwick!

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK and others
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK and others enter.

paragraphs.original:
Doth any name particular belong
Unto the lodging where I first did swoon?
paragraphs.translated: Does the room I first collapsed in have a name?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis called Jerusalem, my noble lord.
paragraphs.translated: It's called the Jerusalem Room, your highness.

paragraphs.original:
Laud be to God! Even there my life must end.
It hath been prophesied to me many years,
I should not die but in Jerusalem,
Which vainly I supposed the Holy Land.
But bear me to that chamber; there I'll lie.
In that Jerusalem shall Harry die.
paragraphs.translated: Praise be to God! That's where I must die. For years it's been predicted that I would die in Jerusalem; I foolishly thought that meant the Holy Land. But carry me to that room, and there I'll lie. In that Jerusalem will Harry die.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter SHALLOW, FALSTAFF, PAGE, and BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW, FALSTAFF, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.

paragraphs.original:
By cock and pie, sir, you shall not away tonight. - What,
Davy, I say!
paragraphs.translated: By gum, sir, you will not leave tonight. Hey, Davy!

paragraphs.original: You must excuse me, Master Robert Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: Please excuse me, Master Robert Shallow.

paragraphs.original:
I will not excuse you. You shall not be excused. Excuses
shall not be admitted. There is no excuse shall serve. You
shall not be excused. - Why, Davy!
paragraphs.translated: I will not excuse you. You will not be excused. Excuses will not be allowed. No excuse will do. You will not be excused. Hey, Davy!

paragraphs.original: Enter DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY enters.

paragraphs.original: Here, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Here, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Davy, Davy, Davy, Davy, let me see, Davy, let me see, Davy,
let me see. Yea, marry, William cook, bid him come
hither. - Sir John, you shall not be excused.
paragraphs.translated: Davy, Davy, Davy, Davy, let's see, Davy, let's see, Davy, let's see. Oh yes, right: tell William the cook to come here. Sir John, you will not be excused.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, sir, thus: those precepts cannot be served. And again,
sir, shall we sow the hade land with wheat?
paragraphs.translated: Well sir, here's the thing. Those warrants couldn't be served. And once more, sir, should we plant wheat at the field's edges?

paragraphs.original:
With red wheat, Davy. But for William cook, are there no
young pigeons?
paragraphs.translated: Plant red wheat, Davy. But as for William the cook - aren't there any young pigeons?

paragraphs.original:
Yes, sir. Here is now the smith's note for shoeing and plow
irons.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir. Here's the bill from the blacksmith for horseshoes and plow blades.

paragraphs.original: Let it be cast and paid. - Sir John, you shall not be excused.
paragraphs.translated: Check the figures and then and pay it. Sir John, you will not be excused.

paragraphs.original:
Now, sir, a new link to the bucket must needs be had. And,
sir, do you mean to stop any of William's wages about the
sack he lost the other day at Hinckley Fair?
paragraphs.translated: Now, sir, we need some new chain for the bucket. And sir, do you plan to dock William's pay for the wine he lost at the Hinckley fair?

paragraphs.original:
He shall answer it. Some pigeons, Davy, a couple of short-
legged hens, a joint of mutton, and any pretty little tiny kickshaws, tell William cook.
paragraphs.translated: He'll pay for that. Some pigeons, Davy; a couple of short-legged hens, a leg of lamb, and any fun little fancy dishes. Tell William the cook.

paragraphs.original: Doth the man of war stay all night, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Is the soldier staying all night?

paragraphs.original:
Yea, Davy. I will use him well. A friend i' th' court is better
than a penny in purse. Use his men well, Davy, for they are
arrant knaves and will backbite.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Davy. I'll take good care of him. A friend at court is better than money in your pocket. Take good care of his men, Davy. They're good-for-nothings, and they'll bite you.

paragraphs.original:
No worse than they are back-bitten, sir, for they have
marvellous foul linen.
paragraphs.translated: No worse than they're bitten, sir. Their clothes are full of lice.

paragraphs.original: Well-conceited, Davy. About thy business, Davy.
paragraphs.translated: Good one, Davy. Get on with your work, Davy.

paragraphs.original:
I beseech you, sir, to countenance William Visor of Woncot
against Clement Perkes o' th' hill.
paragraphs.translated: Please, sir, rule in favor of William Visor of Woncot in his lawsuit against Clement Perkes of the hill.

paragraphs.original:
There is many complaints, Davy, against that Visor. That
Visor is an arrant knave, on my knowledge.
paragraphs.translated: Davy, there are a lot of suits against that Visor. That Visor is a good-for-nothing, as best I can tell.

paragraphs.original:
I grant your Worship that he is a knave, sir, but yet, God
forbid, sir, but a knave should have some countenance at his
friend's request. An honest man, sir, is able to speak for
himself when a knave is not. I have served your Worship
truly, sir, this eight years; an if I cannot once or twice in a
quarter bear out a knave against an honest man, I have
paragraphs.translated: I agree with your honor that he's a good-for-nothing, but God forbid that a good-for-nothing should be denied a favor when his friend asks for one on his behalf. An honest man can speak for himself, but a good-for-nothing can't. I've worked for you for eight years, sir. If I can't get you to rule in favor of a good-

paragraphs.original:
a very little credit with your Worship. The knave is mine
honest friend, sir; therefore I beseech you let him be
countenanced.
paragraphs.translated: for-nothing once in a while, then obviously you don't think very much of me. That good-for-nothing is my good friend, sir. So I ask you, please: rule in his favor.

paragraphs.original: Go to, I say he shall have no wrong. Look about, Davy.
paragraphs.translated: Stop now; I tell you he won't be wronged. Now get going, Davy.

paragraphs.original: Exit DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY exits.

paragraphs.original:
Where are you, Sir John? Come, come, come, off with your
boots. - Give me your hand, Master Bardolph.
paragraphs.translated:
Where are you, Sir John? Come, come, come. Take
your boots off. Let me shake your hand, Master
Bardolph.

paragraphs.original: I am glad to see your Worship.
paragraphs.translated: I'm glad to see you, your honor.

paragraphs.original:
I thank thee with all my heart, kind Master Bardolph, (to the
(to the
PAGE) and welcome, my tall fellow. - Come, Sir John.
)
I'll follow you, good Master Robert Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be right behind you, Master Robert Shallow.

paragraphs.original: Exit SHALLOW
paragraphs.translated: SHALLOW exits.

paragraphs.original: Bardolph, look to our horses.
paragraphs.translated: Bardolph, get our horses ready.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt BARDOLPH and PAGE
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH and the PAGE exit.

paragraphs.original:
If I were sawed into quantities, I should make four dozen of
such bearded hermits' staves as Master Shallow. It is a
wonderful thing to see the semblable coherence of his men's
spirits and his. They, by observing of him, do bear
themselves like foolish justices; he, by conversing with
them, is turned into a justice-like servingman. Their spirits
are so married in conjunction with the participation of
society that they flock together in consent like so many wild
geese. If I had a suit to Master Shallow, I would humor his
men with the imputation of being near their master;if to his
men, I would curry with Master Shallow that no man could
better command his servants. It is certain that either wise
bearing or ignorant carriage is caught, as men take diseases,
one of another. Therefore let men take heed of their
company. I will devise matter enough out of this Shallow to
paragraphs.translated: If I were cut into pieces, I'd make four dozen bearded broomsticks like this Master Shallow. It's amazing to see the similarity between his men's dispositions and his own. They watch him and behave like foolish judges, and he, by associating with them, turns into a judge-like workman. Their spirits are so closely joined by their intimate involvement, they're like a flock of wild geese that fly in formation. If I needed a favor from Judge Shallow, I would make his men think that I'm a close friend of his. If I needed something from his men, I would flatter Shallow by telling him that no one commands servants better than he does. One thing's for sure: the behavior of a wise man and that of an idiot are contagious, like diseases. They spread from person to person, which is why people must be careful about

paragraphs.original: keep Prince Harry in continual laughter the wearing out of six fashions, which is four terms, or two actions, and a' shall laugh without intervallums. O, it is much that a lie with a slight oath and a jest with a sad brow will do with a fellow that never had the ache in his shoulders. O, you shall see him laugh till his face be like a wet cloak ill laid up.
paragraphs.translated: the company they keep. I'll come up with enough material about this Shallow to keep Prince Hal laughing nonstop for a year. That's how much time it takes for the current fashion to change six times, or for two lawsuits to be completed. He'll laugh with no intermission. Oh, a lie told with a measure of truth - or a joke told with a serious face - will go far with a young fellow, who has never had his shoulders weighed down by old age or worries. Oh, he'll laugh until his face looks like a wet coat that was hung poorly - it'll be all wrinkled from laughter.

paragraphs.original:
(within) Sir John.
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Sir John!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original: I come, Master Shallow; I come, Master Shallow.
paragraphs.translated: Coming, Master Shallow! Coming!

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: He exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter WARWICK and the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE
paragraphs.translated: WARWICK and the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE enter.

paragraphs.original: How now, my Lord Chief Justice, whither away?
paragraphs.translated: What's happening, my Lord Chief Justice? Where are you going?

paragraphs.original: How doth the King?
paragraphs.translated: How's the King doing?

paragraphs.original: Exceeding well. His cares are now all ended.
paragraphs.translated: Very well. All his worries are ended now.

paragraphs.original: I hope, not dead.
paragraphs.translated: Not dead, I hope.

paragraphs.original:
He's walked the way of nature,
And to our purposes he lives no more.
paragraphs.translated: He's gone down nature's path; for our purposes, he is no longer living.

paragraphs.original:
I would his Majesty had called me with him.
The service that I truly did his life
Hath left me open to all injuries.
paragraphs.translated: I wish his majesty had brought me with him. The work I did for him while he was alive makes me very vulnerable, now that he's dead.

paragraphs.original: Indeed, I think the young King loves you not.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, I think the young King has no love for you.

paragraphs.original:
I know he doth not, and do arm myself
To welcome the condition of the time,
Which cannot look more hideously upon me
Than I have drawn it in my fantasy.
paragraphs.translated: I know he doesn't. I'm preparing myself to deal with whatever happens, which can't be any worse than what I've imagined.

paragraphs.original: Enter LANCASTER, CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, and others
paragraphs.translated: LANCASTER, CLARENCE, GLOUCESTER, and others enter.

paragraphs.original:
Here come the heavy issue of dead Harry.
O, that the living Harry had the temper
Of he the worst of these three gentlemen!
How many nobles then should hold their places
That must strike sail to spirits of vile sort!
paragraphs.translated: Here come the heavy-hearted children of dead Harry. If only the living Harry had the character of the worst of these three young men. Then a lot of noblemen would remain secure, instead of having to step aside to make room for lowlifes.

paragraphs.original: O God, I fear all will be overturned.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God! I'm afraid everything will be turned upside-down.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, cousin Warwick, good morrow.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, cousin Warwick, good morning.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, cousin.

paragraphs.original: We meet like men that had forgot to speak.
paragraphs.translated: We're all like men who don't remember how to speak.

paragraphs.original:
We do remember, but our argument
Is all too heavy to admit much talk.
paragraphs.translated: We remember how, but what we have to say is so sad that we cannot speak.

paragraphs.original: Well, peace be with him that hath made us heavy.
paragraphs.translated: Well, peace be with the man who has made us sad.

paragraphs.original: Peace be with us, lest we be heavier.
paragraphs.translated: Peace be with us, or else we'll be even sadder!

paragraphs.original:
O, good my lord, you have lost a friend indeed,
And I dare swear you borrow not that face
Of seeming sorrow; it is sure your own.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my good lord, you've lost a friend, indeed. I'm sure you're not borrowing that sorrowful face; it's certainly your own.

paragraphs.original:
Though no man be assured what grace to find,
You stand in coldest expectation.
I am the sorrier; would 'twere otherwise.
paragraphs.translated: Even though no man can know what blessings will come his way, he must expect the worst. I am sorry; I wish it were otherwise.

paragraphs.original:
Well, you must now speak Sir John Falstaff fair,
Which swims against your stream of quality.
paragraphs.translated: Well, now you are only allowed to speak well of Sir John Falstaff, which goes against the nature of a man of your quality.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet princes, what I did I did in honor,
Led by th' impartial conduct of my soul;
And never shall you see that I will beg
A ragged and forestalled remission.
If truth and upright innocency fail me,
I'll to the King my master that is dead
And tell him who hath sent me after him.
paragraphs.translated: Sweet princes, what I did, I did honorably, impartially, and with a clear conscience. You won't see me begging vilely for a pardon, which is sure to be withdrawn as soon as it is given. If truth and honest innocence don't help me, then I'll join my dead King and tell him who sent me.

paragraphs.original: Here comes the Prince.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes the Prince.

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY (now King Henry V), attended
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY (now King Henry V) enters, with attendants.

paragraphs.original: Good morrow, and God save your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: Good morning, and God save your majesty!

paragraphs.original:
This new and gorgeous garment majesty
Sits not so easy on me as you think. - 
Brothers, you mix your sadness with some fear.
This is the English, not the Turkish court;
Not Amurath an Amurath succeeds,
But Harry Harry. Yet be sad, good brothers,
For, by my faith, it very well becomes you.
Sorrow so royally in you appears
That I will deeply put the fashion on
And wear it in my heart. Why then, be sad.
But entertain no more of it, good brothers,
Than a joint burden laid upon us all.
For me, by heaven, I bid you be assured,
I'll be your father and your brother too.
Let me but bear your love, I 'll bear your cares.
Yet weep that Harry's dead, and so will I,
But Harry lives that shall convert those tears
By number into hours of happiness.
paragraphs.translated: This new and gorgeous robe of majesty doesn't fit me as comfortably as you think. Brothers, your sadness is mixed with fear. This is the English court, not the Turkish one. I'm not Amurath, who had his brothers killed when he inherited his father King Amurath's crown; I'm a Harry, following another Harry. But be sad, brothers, because truly, it suits you. You look so regal in your sorrow that I will solemnly put it on as well, and wear it in my heart. Be sad, but don't let it be anything more than a burden we all share jointly. I want you to rest assured that as far as I'm concerned, I'll be both your father and your brother now. Just trust me with your love, and you can trust me to care for you. Keep weeping for Harry, who is dead; I will, as well. But one Harry still lives, and he will convert those tears one by one into hours of happiness.

paragraphs.original: We hope no otherwise from your Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: We hope that's exactly what you'll do.

paragraphs.original:
You all look strangely on me. (to the CHIEF JUSTICE) And you
(to the
)
most.
You are, I think, assured I love you not.

I am assured, if I be measured rightly,
Your Majesty hath no just cause to hate me.
paragraphs.translated: I'm certain that, if my actions are fairly considered, your majesty will find no just reason to hate me.

paragraphs.original:
No?
How might a prince of my great hopes forget
So great indignities you laid upon me?
What, rate, rebuke, and roughly send to prison
Th' immediate heir of England? Was this easy?
May this be washed in Lethe and forgotten?
paragraphs.translated: No? How can a great prince like me forget the terrible wrongs you did me? What were you thinking, to scold, punish, and violently imprison the heir to the English throne? Was this nothing? Should this be dipped in the river of forgetfulness and simply ignored?

paragraphs.original:
I then did use the person of your father;
The image of his power lay then in me.
And in th' administration of his law,
Whiles I was busy for the commonwealth,
Your Highness pleasèd to forget my place,
The majesty and power of law and justice,
The image of the King whom I presented,
And struck me in my very seat of judgment,
Whereon, as an offender to your father,
I gave bold way to my authority
And did commit you. If the deed were ill,
Be you contented, wearing now the garland,
To have a son set your decrees at nought?
To pluck down justice from your awful bench?
To trip the course of law and blunt the sword
That guards the peace and safety of your person?
Nay more, to spurn at your most royal image
And mock your workings in a second body?
Question your royal thoughts, make the case yours;
Be now the father and propose a son,
Hear your own dignity so much profaned,
See your most dreadful laws so loosely slighted,
Behold yourself so by a son disdained,
And then imagine me taking your part
And in your power soft silencing your son.
After this cold considerance, sentence me,
And, as you are a king, speak in your state
paragraphs.translated:
I acted with the authority of your father, whose power was vested in me. And when it came to the law - which I was busy enforcing, for the good of the country - you chose to ignore my rank, and the majesty and power of law and justice which I bore as a representative of the King. You struck me in the head, the very location of my judgment. With that action, you committed a crime against your father's own laws. So I did what my power demanded, and imprisoned you. If that was wrong, then - now that you wear the crown - I hope you'll someday be satisfied with a son who mocks your laws, who scorns the judges who rule in your authority, who disrupts the course of law, and blunts the swords that guard your personal peace and safety.
No, even worse than that: a son who disrespects your deputies, and the officers you appoint in your name. Question yourself, and imagine being in your father's position. Be a father, and imagine a son. Listen to your own dignity being profaned. Watch as your most solemn laws are laughed at so lightly. Behold yourself being so disdained by a son. And then imagine that I take your side, and that in your name I gently silence your son. Soberly consider this, and then pronounce my sentence. As king, tell me

paragraphs.original:
What I have done that misbecame my place,
My person, or my liege's sovereignty.
paragraphs.translated: what I have done that was so unseemly for my station, myself, or my king's authority.

paragraphs.original:
You are right, justice, and you weigh this well.
Therefore still bear the balance and the sword.
And I do wish your honors may increase
Till you do live to see a son of mine
Offend you and obey you as I did.
So shall I live to speak my father's words:
"Happy am I that have a man so bold
That dares do justice on my proper son;
And not less happy, having such a son
That would deliver up his greatness so
Into the hands of justice." You did commit me,
For which I do commit into your hand
Th' unstainèd sword that you have used to bear,
With this remembrance: that you use the same
With the like bold, just, and impartial spirit
As you have done 'gainst me. There is my hand.
You shall be as a father to my youth,
My voice shall sound as you do prompt mine ear,
And I will stoop and humble my intents
To your well-practiced wise directions. - 
And, princes all, believe me, I beseech you:
My father is gone wild into his grave,
For in his tomb lie my affections,
And with his spirit sadly I survive
To mock the expectation of the world,
To frustrate prophecies, and to raze out
Rotten opinion, who hath writ me down
After my seeming. The tide of blood in me
Hath proudly flowed in vanity till now.
Now doth it turn and ebb back to the sea,
Where it shall mingle with the state of floods
And flow henceforth in formal majesty.
Now call we our high court of parliament,
paragraphs.translated:
You're right, Chief Justice, and you have considered this well. Therefore, keep your position as judge and enforcer. I hope that your honors increase, and that you live to see a son of mine offend and then obey you, as I have. I will live to speak my father's words: "I am a happy man, to have a man brave enough to punish my own son; and I'm no less happy to have a son that would surrender his greatness, and put himself in the hands of the law."
You imprisoned me, and for that I charge you to continue in my service, with this reminder: you must always be as courageous, just, and impartial as you were with me. Shake my hand. You'll be like a father to me, and I will say whatever it is you whisper in my ear. I will bow to you, and keep myself humble in the face of your wisdom and experience. And princes, believe me, please: my father lies wild in his grave, for he took my recklessness with him when he died. His sober spirit survives in me, and I will flout the world's expectations. I will prove their prophecies false, and flush out the rotten opinions of those who judged me based on what I once seemed to be.
My behavior, the tide of my blood, used to flow proudly and vainly. But now, it ebbs and turns back toward the sea, where it will mingle with the ocean's majesty and flow back through my body with formal dignity. Now I will assemble my parliament, and choose such noble officers and advisors that our great country will be able to march alongside the best governed nations. We'll become acquainted and familiar

paragraphs.original:
And let us choose such limbs of noble counsel
That the great body of our state may go
In equal rank with the best governed nation;
That war, or peace, or both at once, may be
As things acquainted and familiar to us,
In which you, father, shall have foremost hand.
Our coronation done, we will accite,
As I before remembered, all our state.
And, God consigning to my good intents,
No prince nor peer shall have just cause to say
God shorten Harry's happy life one day.
paragraphs.translated:
with the states of war, peace, or both at once; in this, Chief Justice, my new father, you will be my closest advisor.
Once my coronation has been completed, I will, as I said before, summon all the nobility. And if God endorses my good intentions, no prince or lord will have reason to say that he wishes God would shorten my happy life by even a single day.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, SILENCE, DAVY, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, SILENCE, DAVY, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.

paragraphs.original:
Nay, you shall see my orchard, where, in an arbor, we will
eat a last year's pippin of my own graffing, with a dish of
caraways, and so forth. - Come, cousin Silence. - And then
to bed.
paragraphs.translated: No, you're going to see my orchard. We'll sit in an arbor and eat some of the pippin apples I cross-bred last season, along with some caraway seeds and so on. Come on, Silence. Then we'll go to bed.

paragraphs.original: Fore God, you have here a goodly dwelling and a rich.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, you have a good-looking place here, and it's fancy.

paragraphs.original:
Barren, barren, barren, beggars all, beggars all, Sir John.
Marry, good air. - Spread, Davy, spread, Davy. Well said,
Davy.
paragraphs.translated: Cheap, cheap, cheap. We're broke, broke, Sir John. But one thing we do have is good air. Set the table, Davy, set the table. Good job, Davy.

paragraphs.original:
This Davy serves you for good uses. He is your servingman
and your husband.
paragraphs.translated: This Davy does a lot for you. He's your right-hand man as well as your steward.

paragraphs.original:
A good varlet, a good varlet, a very good varlet, Sir John. By
the Mass, I have drunk too much sack at supper. A good
varlet. Now sit down, now sit down. - Come, cousin.
paragraphs.translated: A good servant, a very good servant, Sir John. By God, I had too much wine with dinner. A good servant. Now sit down, sit down. Come on, cousin.

paragraphs.original:
Ah, sirrah, quoth he, we shall
Do nothing but eat and make good cheer,
(sings) And praise God for the merry year,
(sings)
When flesh is cheap and females dear,
And lusty lads roam here and there
So merrily,
And ever among so merrily.
paragraphs.translated:
Ah, Sirrah, he said. We will:
Do nothing but eat and celebrate,
(sings) And praise God for this happy year,
(sings)
When flesh is cheap but women are costly,
And lusty men roam here and there,
So merrily,
And always so merrily.

paragraphs.original:
There's a merry heart! - Good Master Silence, I'll give you
a health for that anon.
paragraphs.translated: That's a merry heart! Master Silence, I'll drink a toast to you in a minute.

paragraphs.original: Give Master Bardolph some wine, Davy.
paragraphs.translated: Davy, get Master Bardolph some wine.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet sir, sit. I'll be with you anon. Most sweet sir, sit.
Master page, good master page, sit. Proface. What you want
in meat, we'll have in drink, but you must bear. The heart's
all.
paragraphs.translated: Sit, kind sir; I'll be with you in a second. Very kind sir, please sit. Here's to you! What we lack in food, we make up for in drink. You must endure it; good intentions are what count.

paragraphs.original: Exit DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY exits.

paragraphs.original:
Be merry, Master Bardolph.  - And, my little soldier there,
be merry.
paragraphs.translated: Enjoy yourself, Master Bardolph, and you, my little soldier, enjoy yourself.

paragraphs.original:
(sings) Be merry, be merry, my wife has all,
(sings)
For women are shrews, both short and tall.
'Tis merry in hall when beards wag all,
And welcome merry Shrovetide.
Be merry, be merry.
paragraphs.translated:
(sings) Enjoy, enjoy! My wife has it all,
(sings)
Women are shrews, whether they're short or they're tall,
It's a merry party when men laugh and joke,
So let's enjoy ourselves this
Shrovetide,
Shrovetide



Enjoy, enjoy!

paragraphs.original: I did not think Master Silence had been a man of this mettle.
paragraphs.translated: I didn't think Master Silence had this in him.

paragraphs.original: Who, I? I have been merry twice and once ere now.
paragraphs.translated: Who, me? I've let loose once or twice in my life.

paragraphs.original: Enter DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY enters.
(to BARDOLPH) Here's a dish of red apples for you.

paragraphs.original: Davy!
paragraphs.translated: Davy!

paragraphs.original:
Your Worship, I'll be with you straight. - 
(to BARDOLPH) A cup of wine, sir?
(to
)

(sings) A cup of wine that's brisk and fine,
(sings)
And drink unto thee, leman mine,
And a merry heart lives long-a.
paragraphs.translated:
(sings) A cup of wine that's fresh and fine,
(sings)
And drink to you, darling mine,
And a happy heart lives long!

paragraphs.original: Well said, Master Silence.
paragraphs.translated: Well said, Master Silence.

paragraphs.original: And we shall be merry; now comes in the sweet o' th' night.
paragraphs.translated: And we will enjoy ourselves. Now's the best time of night.

paragraphs.original: Health and long life to you, Master Silence.
paragraphs.translated: Here's to your health and long life, Master Silence.

paragraphs.original:
(sings) Fill the cup, and let it come,
(sings)
I'll pledge you a mile to th' bottom.
paragraphs.translated:
(sings) Fill the cup, and pass it here,
(sings)
I'll drink it to the bottom, even if it's a mile down.

paragraphs.original:
Honest Bardolph, welcome. If thou wantest anything and
wilt not call, beshrew thy heart. - 
(to the PAGE) Welcome, my little tiny thief, and welcome
(to the
)
indeed too. I'll drink to Master Bardolph, and to all the
cabileros about London.
I hope to see London once ere I die.
paragraphs.translated: I hope to see London once before I die.

paragraphs.original: An I might see you there, Davy!
paragraphs.translated: If I see you there, Davy -

paragraphs.original:
By the Mass, you'll crack a quart together, ha, will you not,
Master Bardolph?
paragraphs.translated: By God, you'll break open a quart bottle together, ha! Won't you, Master Bardolph?

paragraphs.original: Yea, sir, in a pottle-pot.
paragraphs.translated: Yessir, in a two-quart glass.

paragraphs.original:
By God's liggens, I thank thee. The knave will stick by thee,
I can assure thee that. He will not out, he. 'Tis true bred!
paragraphs.translated: By God's fingers, I thank you. This rogue will stick with you, I promise you that. He won't fail, he's true blue.

paragraphs.original: And I'll stick by him, sir.
paragraphs.translated: And I'll stick with him, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Why, there spoke a king. Lack nothing, be merry.
One knocks at the door within
Look who's at door there, ho. Who knocks?
paragraphs.translated:
Spoken like a king. Take whatever you want: enjoy yourselves!
Knocking is heard offstage.
Knocking is heard offstage.
Hey, see who's at the door there! Who's knocking?

paragraphs.original: Exit DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY exits.

paragraphs.original:
(sings) Do me right,
(sings)
And dub me knight,
Samingo.
Is 't not so?
paragraphs.translated:
(sings) Keep up with me,
(sings)
Then dub me a knight!
Samingo!
Samingo



Right?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis so.
paragraphs.translated: Right.

paragraphs.original: Is 't so? Why then, say an old man can do somewhat.
paragraphs.translated: Right? Then you've got to admit that an old man can do some things.

paragraphs.original: Enter DAVY
paragraphs.translated: DAVY returns.

paragraphs.original:
An 't please your Worship, there's one Pistol come from the
court with news.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, if I may say so, there's someone named Pistol here from the royal court. He's got news.

paragraphs.original: From the court? Let him come in.
paragraphs.translated: From the royal court? Let him in.

paragraphs.original: Enter PISTOL
paragraphs.translated: PISTOL enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, Pistol?
paragraphs.translated: What's up, Pistol!

paragraphs.original: Sir John, God save you.
paragraphs.translated: God save you, Sir John.

paragraphs.original: What wind blew you hither, Pistol?
paragraphs.translated: What wind blew you here, Pistol?

paragraphs.original:
Not the ill wind which blows no man to good. Sweet knight,
thou art now one of the greatest men in this realm.
paragraphs.translated: Not the evil wind that blows no one toward any good. Sweet knight, you are now one of the hugest men in the country.

paragraphs.original: By 'r Lady, I think he be, but Goodman Puff of Barson.
paragraphs.translated: I swear, I think he is - except for the good fellow Puff, from Barson.

paragraphs.original:
Puff?
Puff in thy teeth, most recreant coward base! - 
Sir John, I am thy Pistol and thy friend,
And helter-skelter have I rode to thee,
And tidings do I bring, and lucky joys,
And golden times, and happy news of price.
paragraphs.translated: Puff? Puff in your face, you degenerate coward! Sir John, I'm your Pistol and your friend, and I rode at full tilt to find you here. I bring you reports, and good luck, and golden times, and happy, valuable news.

paragraphs.original: I pray thee now, deliver them like a man of this world.
paragraphs.translated: Then please, deliver this news like a human being who lives in this world.

paragraphs.original:
A foutre for the world and worldlings base!
I speak of Africa and golden joys.
paragraphs.translated: Damn this world, and the vile little people who live in it! I'm talking about Africa, and its golden joys.

paragraphs.original:
O base Assyrian knight, what is thy news?
Let King Cophetua know the truth thereof.
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, you vulgar Assyrian knight, what is your news? Convey to
King Cophetua the story therein.
King Cophetua

paragraphs.original:
(sings) And Robin Hood, Scarlet, and John.
(sings)
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
And Robin Hood, Scarlet, and John.
(sings)
And Robin Hood, Scarlet, and John

paragraphs.original:
Shall dunghill curs confront the Helicons,
And shall good news be baffled?
Then, Pistol, lay thy head in Furies' lap.
paragraphs.translated: Will junkyard dogs attack the Muses, goddesses of poetry? Will my good news be thwarted this way? Then Pistol, go ahead and plead with the Furies, the goddesses of revenge.

paragraphs.original: Honest gentleman, I know not your breeding.
paragraphs.translated: Honest gentleman, I don't know what kind of family you're from.

paragraphs.original: Why then, lament therefor.
paragraphs.translated: That's your loss.

paragraphs.original:
Give me pardon, sir. If, sir, you come with news from the
court, I take it there's but two ways, either to utter them, or
to conceal them. I am, sir, under the King in some authority.
paragraphs.translated: Forgive me saying so, sir, but if you've got news from the court, then you have only two choices: you can either tell it or not tell it. I have some authority from the King, you know.

paragraphs.original: Under which king, besonian? Speak or die.
paragraphs.translated: From which king, you beggar? Speak, or die.

paragraphs.original: Under King Harry.
paragraphs.translated: For King Henry.

paragraphs.original: Harry the Fourth, or Fifth?
paragraphs.translated: Henry the Fourth, or Fifth?

paragraphs.original: Harry the Fourth.
paragraphs.translated: Henry the Fourth.

paragraphs.original:
A foutre for thine office! - 
Sir John, thy tender lambkin now is king.
Harry the Fifth's the man. I speak the truth.
When Pistol lies, do this (he makes an obscene gesture) and
he makes an obscene gesture)
fig me, like
The bragging Spaniard.
paragraphs.translated:
Then screw your position! Sir John, your tender little lamb is now the king. Henry the Fifth's the man, and I speak the truth. When Pistol tells a lie, do this (he makes an obscene gesture) and tell me to go screw myself, like some crazy Spaniard.
(he makes an obscene gesture)

paragraphs.original: What, is the old king dead?
paragraphs.translated: What? Is the old King dead?

paragraphs.original: As nail in door. The things I speak are just.
paragraphs.translated: As a doornail: these things I say are true.

paragraphs.original:
Away, Bardolph. - Saddle my horse. - Master Robert
Shallow, choose what office thou wilt in the land,
'tis thine. Pistol, I will double-charge thee with dignities.
paragraphs.translated: Get going, Bardolph! Saddle up my horse. Master Robert Shallow, pick whatever job you want in the whole country: it's yours. Pistol, I'll pile honors on you.

paragraphs.original: O joyful day! I would not take a knighthood for my fortune.
paragraphs.translated: Oh happy day! I wouldn't even trade a knighthood for my new, good fortune.

paragraphs.original: What, I do bring good news!
paragraphs.translated: There you go! I brought good news!

paragraphs.original:
Carry Master Silence to bed. - Master Shallow, my Lord
Shallow, be what thou wilt. I am Fortune's steward. Get on
paragraphs.translated: Carry Master Silence to bed. Master Shallow - Lord Shallow - call yourself whatever you want. I'm in

paragraphs.original:
thy boots. We'll ride all night. - O sweet Pistol! - Away,
Bardolph!
paragraphs.translated: charge of all the luck in the world! Get your boots on. We'll ride through the night. Oh sweet Pistol! Get going, Bardolph!

paragraphs.original: Exit BARDOLPH
paragraphs.translated: BARDOLPH exits.

paragraphs.original:
Come, Pistol, utter more to me, and withal devise something
to do thyself good. Boot, boot, Master Shallow. I know the
young King is sick for me. Let us take any man's horses. The
laws of England are at my commandment. Blessed are they
that have been my friends, and woe to my Lord Chief
Justice!
paragraphs.translated: Pistol, tell me more, and help me think of something good we can do for you. Boots, boots, Master Shallow! I know the young King is dying to see me. Let's just take anybody's horses; I rule the laws of England now! Blessed are those who have been my friends, and watch out, Lord Chief Justice!

paragraphs.original:
Let vultures vile seize on his lungs also!
"Where is the life that late I led?" say they.
Why, here it is. Welcome these pleasant days.
paragraphs.translated: May vultures eat out his lungs, too! You know the old saying, "What happened to the life I used to lead?" Well, they're here; welcome to these pleasant days.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter BEADLES, dragging in MISTRESS QUICKLY and DOLL TEARSHEET
paragraphs.translated: BEADLES enter, dragging DOLL TEARSHEET and MISTRESS QUICKLY.

paragraphs.original:
No, thou arrant knave. I would to God that I might die, that
I might have thee hanged. Thou hast drawn my shoulder out
of joint.
paragraphs.translated: No, you horrible rogue! I wish to God I were dead, so I could have you hanged. You dislocated my shoulder!

paragraphs.original:
The Constables have delivered her over to me, and she shall
have whipping cheer enough, I warrant her. There hath been
a man or two lately killed about her.
paragraphs.translated: The street cops handed her over to me, and she'll be whipped through and through, I promise. She's been involved in a couple of murders.

paragraphs.original:
Nut-hook, nut-hook, you lie! Come on, I 'll tell thee what,
thou damned tripe-visaged rascal: an the child I now go with
do miscarry, thou wert better thou hadst struck thy mother,
thou paper-faced villain.
paragraphs.translated: Pig, Pig! You lie! Come on! I'll tell you what, you damned flabby-faced moron: if I have a miscarriage now, you'll wish you'd hit your own mother, you pasty-faced villain!

paragraphs.original:
O the Lord, that Sir John were come! I would make this a
bloody day to somebody. But I pray God the fruit of her
womb might miscarry.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God, I wish Sir John would come! He'd make somebody bleed for this. I pray to God that she has a miscarriage!

paragraphs.original:
If it do, you shall have a dozen of cushions again; you have
but eleven now. Come, I charge you both go with me, for the
man is dead that you and Pistol beat amongst you.
paragraphs.translated: Well, if she does, you'll have twelve cushions on your couch again. You have only eleven now, since she's wearing one of them under her dress. I order both of you to come with me: the man that you two and Pistol beat up is dead.

paragraphs.original:
I'll tell you what, you thin man in a censer, I will have you
as soundly swinged for this, you bluebottle rogue, you filthy
famished correctioner. If you be not swinged, I'll forswear
half-kirtles.
