paragraphs.translated: I'll tell you what, you stick-figure; I'll have you beaten soundly for this. You blue-coated rogue, you filthy, starving correctioner! If you aren't walloped for this, I'll swear off skirts.

paragraphs.original: Come, come, you she knight-errant, come.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, come on, you little night sinner, come on.

paragraphs.original:
O God, that right should thus overcome might! Well, of
sufferance comes ease.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God! I can't believe that right is overcoming might! Well, challenges build character.

paragraphs.original: Come, you rogue, come, bring me to a justice.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you bastard, come on. Bring me to a judge.

paragraphs.original: Ay, come, you starved bloodhound.
paragraphs.translated: Yeah, come on, you starved dog.

paragraphs.original: Goodman Death, Goodman Bones!
paragraphs.translated: Master Death! Master Bones!

paragraphs.original: Thou atomy, thou!
paragraphs.translated: You skeleton, you!

paragraphs.original: Come, you thin thing, come, you rascal.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you thin thing; come on, you lean deer!

paragraphs.original: Very well.
paragraphs.translated: Very well.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter two GROOMS, strewing rushes
paragraphs.translated:
Two
GROOMS enter, strewing rushes to cover the floors.

paragraphs.original: More rushes, more rushes.
paragraphs.translated: More rushes; more rushes.

paragraphs.original: The trumpets have sounded twice.
paragraphs.translated: The trumpets have blown twice.

paragraphs.original:
'Twill be two o'clock ere they come from the coronation.
Dispatch, dispatch.
paragraphs.translated: It'll be two o'clock before they arrive from the coronation. Hurry, hurry.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and PAGE
paragraphs.translated: FALSTAFF, SHALLOW, PISTOL, BARDOLPH, and the PAGE enter.

paragraphs.original:
Stand here by me, Master Robert Shallow. I will make the
King do you grace. I will leer upon him as he comes by, and
do but mark the countenance that he will give me.
paragraphs.translated: Stand here near me, Master Robert Shallow. I'll make the King do good things for you: I'll throw him a look as he passes by. Just watch the face he'll make at me.

paragraphs.original: God bless thy lungs, good knight!
paragraphs.translated: God bless your lungs, good knight.

paragraphs.original:
Come here, Pistol, stand behind me. - (to SHALLOW) O, if I
(to
)
had had time to have made new liveries, I would have
bestowed the thousand pound I borrowed of you. But 'tis no
matter. This poor show doth better. This doth infer the zeal
I had to see him.
It doth so.
paragraphs.translated: It does indeed.

paragraphs.original: It shows my earnestness of affection -
paragraphs.translated: It shows how sincerely I love him -

paragraphs.original: It doth so.
paragraphs.translated: It does indeed.

paragraphs.original: My devotion -
paragraphs.translated: My devotion -

paragraphs.original: It doth, it doth, it doth.
paragraphs.translated: It does, it does, it does.

paragraphs.original:
As it were, to ride day and night, and not to deliberate, not
to remember, not to have patience to shift me -
paragraphs.translated: In a word, to ride all night; not to stop and think, not to dawdle, not to take the time to change my clothes -

paragraphs.original: It is best, certain.
paragraphs.translated: It is best, no doubt about it.

paragraphs.original:
But to stand stained with travel and sweating with desire to
see him, thinking of nothing else, putting all affairs else in
oblivion, as if there were nothing else to be done but to see
him.
paragraphs.translated: Standing here filthy from traveling, and sweating with my desire to see him; thinking of nothing else, disregarding everything, as if the only thing in the world that mattered was seeing him.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis semper idem, for obsque hoc nihil est;
semper idem
obsque hoc nihil est
'tis all in every part.
paragraphs.translated:
That's how it is. Nothing else matters.
Semper idem. Obsque hoc nihil est.
Semper idem. Obsque hoc nihil est

paragraphs.original: 'Tis so indeed.
paragraphs.translated: That's exactly right.

paragraphs.original:
My knight, I will inflame thy noble liver, and make thee
rage. Thy Doll and Helen of thy noble thoughts is in base
durance and contagious prison, Haled thither by most
mechanical and dirty hand. Rouse up revenge from ebon den
with fell Alecto's snake, for Doll is in. Pistol speaks nought
but truth.
paragraphs.translated: Knight, I'll fire up your noble liver and make you enraged. Doll, the goddess of your thoughts, is imprisoned in a horrible jail, tossed there by a heartless and filthy hand. Stoke up dark revenge from your deepest belly and set loose the serpents of hell. Doll is in. Pistol speaks nothing but the truth.

paragraphs.original: I will deliver her.
paragraphs.translated: I'll set her free.

paragraphs.original: Shouts within, and the trumpets sound
paragraphs.translated: Shouts are heard offstage. Trumpets play.

paragraphs.original: There roared the sea, and trumpet-clangor sounds.
paragraphs.translated: That was the roar of the sea. The clanging trumpet sounds!

paragraphs.original: Enter PRINCE HENRY and his train, the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE among them
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY enters with a procession of attendants, including the CHIEF JUSTICE.

paragraphs.original: God save thy Grace, King Hal, my royal Hal.
paragraphs.translated: God save your grace, King Hal! My royal Hal!

paragraphs.original: The heavens thee guard and keep, most royal imp of fame!
paragraphs.translated: The heavens guard and protect you, you royal child of fame!

paragraphs.original: God save thee, my sweet boy!
paragraphs.translated: God save you, my sweet boy!

paragraphs.original: My Lord Chief Justice, speak to that vain man.
paragraphs.translated: My Lord Chief Justice, go speak to that arrogant man.

paragraphs.original:
(to FALSTAFF) Have you your wits? Know you what 'tis to
(to
)
speak?
My King, my Jove, I speak to thee, my heart!
paragraphs.translated: My King! My God! I'm talking to you, my heart!

paragraphs.original:
I know thee not, old man. Fall to thy prayers.
How ill white hairs become a fool and jester.
I have long dreamt of such a kind of man,
So surfeit-swelled, so old, and so profane;
But being awaked, I do despise my dream.
Make less thy body hence, and more thy grace;
Leave gormandizing. Know the grave doth gape
For thee thrice wider than for other men.
Reply not to me with a fool-born jest.
Presume not that I am the thing I was,
For God doth know - so shall the world perceive - 
That I have turned away my former self.
So will I those that kept me company.
When thou dost hear I am as I have been,
Approach me, and thou shalt be as thou wast,
The tutor and the feeder of my riots.
Till then I banish thee, on pain of death,
As I have done the rest of my misleaders,
paragraphs.translated:
I know you not, old man. Get down on your knees and pray, for white hair doesn't sit well on a fool and a clown. I have dreamed about such a man for a long time: a man so swollen with excess, so old and so obscene. But now that I have awakened, I despise that dream. Let your body lessen, and your manners increase; leave behind your overindulgence, and know that the grave gapes three times as wide for you than any other man. Don't answer me with a foolish joke. Do not assume that I am what I was; for God knows, I have turned my back on my former self, and I will do the same to those who were my companions. When you hear that I am as I was, then come to me, and you will once again be what you were: the teacher and nurse to my wild, riotous ways.
Until then, I banish you, on pain of death, as I have done to the other men who once misled me. Do not

paragraphs.original:
Not to come near our person by ten mile.
For competence of life I will allow you,
That lack of means enforce you not to evils.
And, as we hear you do reform yourselves,
We will, according to your strengths and qualities,
Give you advancement. (to CHIEF JUSTICE) Be it your charge,
(to
)
my lord,
To see performed the tenor of my word. - 
Set on.
Exeunt PRINCE HENRY, the CHIEF JUSTICE, and the attendants.
paragraphs.translated: PRINCE HENRY, the CHIEF JUSTICE, and the attendants exit.

paragraphs.original: Master Shallow, I owe you a thousand pound.
paragraphs.translated: Master Shallow, I owe you a thousand pounds.

paragraphs.original:
Yea, marry, Sir John, which I beseech you to let me have
home with me.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, indeed, Sir John. And I'd like to take it home with me.

paragraphs.original:
That can hardly be, Master Shallow. Do not you grieve at
this. I shall be sent for in private to him. Look you, he must
seem thus to the world. Fear not your advancements. I will
be the man yet that shall make you great.
paragraphs.translated: That can't happen, Master Shallow. Don't let this upset you; I'll get a private invitation to see him. Look, he has to appear this way to the world. Don't worry about your good fortunes: I'm still the man who will make you great.

paragraphs.original:
I cannot well perceive how, unless you should give me your
doublet and stuff me out with straw. I beseech you, good Sir
John, let me have five hundred of my thousand.
paragraphs.translated: I don't know how you're going to do that, unless you give me your jacket and fill me out with stuffing. Please, Sir John, let me have five hundred of my thousand.

paragraphs.original:
Sir, I will be as good as my word. This that you heard was
but a color.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I'm as good as my word. What you heard here a minute ago was just a color; it was a pretense.

paragraphs.original: A color that I fear you will die in, Sir John.
paragraphs.translated: A color that I fear you'll be buried in, Sir John.

paragraphs.original:
Fear no colors. Go with me to dinner. - Come, Lieutenant
Pistol. - Come, Bardolph. - I shall be sent for soon at night.
paragraphs.translated: Stop worrying about colors: come to lunch with me. Come, Lieutenant Pistol. Come, Bardolph. He'll call for me tonight.

paragraphs.original: Enter the Lord CHIEF JUSTICE and Prince John of LANCASTER; officers with them
paragraphs.translated: The Lord CHIEF JUSTICE, Prince John of LANCASTER, and officers enter.

paragraphs.original:
Go, carry Sir John Falstaff to the Fleet.
Take all his company along with him.
paragraphs.translated: Go, take Sir John Falstaff away to jail, and take all his companions with him.

paragraphs.original: My lord, my lord -
paragraphs.translated: My lord, my lord -

paragraphs.original:
I cannot now speak. I will hear you soon. - 
Take them away.
paragraphs.translated: I can't talk now. I'll listen to you later. Take them away.

paragraphs.original:
Si fortune me tormenta, spero me contenta.
Si fortune me tormenta, spero me contenta.
paragraphs.translated:
Si fortuna me tormenta, spero me contenta.
Si fortuna me tormenta, spero me contenta

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but Prince John of LANCASTER andthe CHIEF JUSTICE
paragraphs.translated: Everyone exits except John of LANCASTER and the CHIEF JUSTICE.

paragraphs.original:
I like this fair proceeding of the King's.
He hath intent his wonted followers
Shall all be very well provided for,
But all are banished till their conversations
Appear more wise and modest to the world.
paragraphs.translated: The King's fair dealings please me. He wants to ensure that his old companions are provided for, but he banishes them until they can behave more properly and presentably.

paragraphs.original: And so they are.
paragraphs.translated: That they are.

paragraphs.original: The King hath called his parliament, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: The King's assembled his parliament, sir.

paragraphs.original: He hath.
paragraphs.translated: He has.

paragraphs.original:
I will lay odds that, ere this year expire,
We bear our civil swords and native fire
As far as France: I beard a bird so sing,
Whose music, to my thinking, pleased the King.
Come, will you hence?
paragraphs.translated: I'll bet that, before the year ends, we'll launch an invasion of France. I heard a little bird singing about it, and I think the music pleased the King. Come, will you leave with me?

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter the EPILOGUE.
paragraphs.translated:
The
EPILOGUE enters.

paragraphs.original:
First my fear; then my curtsy, last my speech. My fear is your
displeasure my curtsy my duty; and my speech, to beg your
pardons. If you look for a good speech now, you undo me,
for what I have to say is of mine own making, and what
indeed I should say will, I doubt, prove mine own marring.
But to the purpose, and so to the venture. Be it known to you,
as it is very well, I was lately here in the end of a displeasing
play to pray your patience for it and to promise you a better.
I meant indeed to pay you with this, which, if like an ill
venture it come unluckily home, I break, and you, my gentle
creditors, lose. Here I promised you I would be, and here I
commit my body to your mercies. Bate me some, and I will
pay you some, and, as most debtors do, promise you
infinitely. And so I kneel down before you, but, indeed, to
pray for the Queen.
If my tongue cannot entreat you to acquit me, will you
command me to use my legs? And yet that were but light
payment, to dance out of your debt. But a good conscience
will make any possible satisfaction, and so would I. All the
gentlewomen here have forgiven me; if the gentlemen will
not, then the gentlemen do not agree with the gentlewomen,
which was never seen before in such an assembly.
One word more, I beseech you: if you be not too much
cloyed with fat meat, our humble author will continue the
story, with Sir John in it, and make you merry with fair
Katherine of France, where, for anything I know, Falstaff
shall die of a sweat, unless already he be killed with your
hard opinions; for Oldcastle died a martyr, and this is not
the man. My tongue is weary; when my legs are too, I will
bid you good night.
paragraphs.translated:
First, I'll tell you what I'm afraid of. Then, I'll bow, and finally, I'll make a speech. I fear that this play displeased you; I bow to you out of duty; and finally, I make this speech to ask you for forgiveness. If you're expecting a good speech now, then I'm in trouble. For I wrote the words I'm about to say, and I'm sure that what I'm about to say will end up getting me in trouble. But I'll get to the point, and thus I'll get to the danger. You should know - as you seem to - that I recently came on this stage at the end of some other lousy play, to ask you to be patient and to promise you a better play the next time. I had intended to pay you back for that play with this one. If you didn't like this play, then - like a businessman who has gambled on a risky venture - I am bankrupt; and you, my sweet creditors, are out of luck. I promised you I would be here, and here I stand to submit myself to your mercy. Give me some mercy and I'll promise to pay you back again another time. That's how debtors do it: they always promise to repay.
If my talking can't convince you to let me off the hook, then would you like me to dance? And yet, that would be a cheap payment, to dance myself out of debt. But a person with a good conscience will always seek to pay his debts, and I would do the same. All the women here have forgiven me: if the men won't, then the men don't agree with the women, which has never happened in a theater audience before.
Just one more thing, if you don't mind. If fatty meat hasn't clogged you up yet, our playwright will continue the story with Sir John in it, and entertain you with the beautiful Princess Katharine of France. And speaking of France, as far as I know, Falstaff will die there of the sweating disease - unless, that is, he's already been killed by your low opinions of him.
Oldcastle died a martyr, and this is not him. My mouth is tired; when my legs are, too, I'll say goodnight and take a bow.
Oldcastle
